Combat actually feels dangerous, and requires you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. It's exactly what you would expect from a well-reviewed game in the same format as EotB. I really enjoyed Grimrock, but it's not without flaws. The enemy AI is bad. Really, really bad. You can kite everything. It's practically required at points (and therefore I'm fairly certain it's an intentional "feature"), but it feels and looks really stupid to dance around a 2x2 square stabbing wildly whenever the enemy walks into your line of sight. Some of the hidden switches (those specific to getting treasure, NOT clearing the floors) are very hard to find. It's not a bad thing necessarily, but if you want to get the best gear you'll likely need a guide. Inventory management is cumbersome, because you cannot have more than one character's bag open at a time. Before you begin, you don't know what kind of gear you're going to find, meaning you can dump a bunch of early points into, say, Armour on your Fighter, but not have any heavy armour to take advantage of it. This problem is particularly bad for mages, who rely on you finding hidden scrolls to learn new spells (or cheating and looking them up online...), and can have 20 points invested in a tree they only have the first couple spells for. You're never sure if you missed the scrolls, or if they're just further along. There are some weird things with items, too. Occasionally you won't pick up an arrow you fired, leaving you to go hunting for it after the battle (not fun). You can't use a mortar and pestle from inside a container, meaning all your Alchemy materials have to stay in a character's inventory (10+ bottles, 6 reagants, and the Mortar takes up about half that guy's bag). You find weird things all over, some of which you will want later and some of which are just garbage. It's impossible to know which ones are critical to your mission (or hunt for treasure), though, because there isn't any tagging. And it's not like the game ASKS for this sword you found to be in your inventory. There's no prompt saying "No entry without sword." It's a silent check that you either pass or fail, and without a guide you might never know it was even there. You'll notice none of the issues I had with the game are anything close to being "game-breaking." They're just minor, quality of life things (and most of them are things that, if changed, would dramatically decrease how difficult the game is). It really is incredibly well polished, especially for an indie game. If you're curious, I'd put the game at about 20 hours in length if you go exploring. It's far easier than EotB, both because the updated graphics give you better depth perception and because it has a built-in map+healing crystals. It's still challenging, though, it's fairly priced, and although not without flaws I would recommend Grimrock to anyone who likes old-school CRPGs. Just be sure to read the manual before you start, and always keep an extra torch or five handy. You never know when you'll need them.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												Legend of Grimrock is an excellent, atmospheric, well-made RPG in the style of much, MUCH older gems of the early 90's. The square-based movement style, and D&D style stats and gearing up, as well as the different patterns and intricacies of every enemy makes every encounter challenging, but not overpowering.Legend of Grimrock has incredible atmosphere. In the tight, packed corridors, you feel constantly trapped in a labarinth of passages, doors and levers. With over seventy secrets, treasures and notes, Grimrock's focus on exploration never dilutes the main path, meaning that you can explore each area as much or as little as you want.Legend of Grimrock's puzzles are very well made. Some require pinpoint reflexes and timing, while some require a more calculated and steady approach, but none feel impossible save one or two truly evil puzzles. The difficulty setting, however, is a tad arbitrary. Difficulty affects enemy stats and your hunger bar, but aside from that it changes nothing. Playing the game on easy will give you a much more enjoyable experience, and will not mean that a death of a party member is permanent.That being said, I only experienced one game-over screen and that was due to my own misstep on the final boss (who is definately innovative, if a tad underwhelming).This game is an excellent purchase, and a guaranteed source of enjoyment for a good ten or so hours, provided you do a full playthrough, fifteen if you're unfamilliar with the genre. The exploration bonus character makes for another interesting experience, so it may be wise to play through the game twice over - perhaps using a guide to help on the second time around.In conclusion, Legend of Grimrock is a bonafide gem of a game, and I would reccomend this to any fan of RPG's

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2014
												This game follows in the footsteps of games like Eye of the Beholder, yet gets lost along the way.Mainly this game is trying to take an RPG and make it a strategy/ puzzle crawler, instead of a dungeon crawler.  In order to succeed at this game you can't fight monsters toe to toe.  The game seems to be designed in a way that you must exploit the game mechanics (taking a swing at a monster then retreating before it can attack) in order to survive.  This combined with constant puzzles instead of exploring, make this game a poor choice for anyone looking for a true RPG dungeon crawler game.Party creation is also mediocre, with a minimum selection of classes, and non dynamic races.  You also only get a 4 person party instead of 6 which also limits experience.The game also has a combat interface that is clunkier than I remember the Eye of the Beholder games to be.  You can equip two weapons on a chanracter, but can't use them at the same time.  Also the spell system tried to be inovative with a rune selection process to make spell casting more of a challenge in the heat of battle.  However, the spell interface needs to be opened each time and has some issues.Also food seems to be unevenly distributed in the dungeons, making me wonder if food was initially and after thought of the game, and then made into a major mechanic at the last minute.  It seems to be laid out that if you try and 'clean' the dungeon by exploring every inch of a level, your party will starve to death.  However since the game is based on puzzles to unlock the next dungeon, complete exploration is usually a must.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2014
												In my world, Legend Of Grimrock would be called "The reincarnation of Eye Of The Beholder", or something of the sort, as I have really good memories of the first Eye Of The Beholder game from the early 1990s (although I never beat it), and Legend Of Grimrock looks just like it. Just recently I realized Eye Of The Beholder itself was a reincarnation (or what some people would call "a clone" or "a ripoff") of a similar game called "Dungeon Master" from the 1980s (which I've never heard of until recently), but 'nuff said about that.Back to Legend Of Grimrock -The game is a first person dungeon crawling Action/RPG. You play a group of 4 adventurers (aka convicted criminals, but nevermind about that :P), whose goal is to survive the dungeon by means of solving puzzles and fighting monsters while staying alive in the process. The default party consists of two fighters (one human, one minotaur), one wizard and one rogue, set in a fixed formation of two rows - two characters in front, two more behind them. You can choose which character to place where and change it while playing, but you can't change the formation. The idea is that the two front characters use melee attacks, while the other two need to attack from long range (either magic, throwing weapons such as knives, or missile weapons such as bows).Up until now (8-10 hours ingame), I'm really having fun. Technically, everything looks and feels good. There's nothing overwhelming about the graphics or the music, but they are definitely good enough. Come to think of it, there's hardly any music ingame, and I think it's a really good idea. The lack of music makes the game feel more realistic, and it lets you pay the worthy attention to the sound effects, which just like with Eye Of The Beholder, play an important role, as they serve as warning signs from certain enemies.  The controls are simple and intuitive (left click to move items, right click to attack when it comes to battles). Some of the puzzles are very easy, others are more difficult. I did find it necessary to look for help online in a couple of incidents so far, but I did manage to solve most of the puzzles myself (up to where I am at the moment, can't say anything about the puzzles I haven't reached yet). All in all, this game is fun. If you like dungeon crawlers, get it. It might not be a masterpiece, but it is fun to play.

content:
er 15, 2016
												I know many people loved it, but this is not my kind of game.I expected the combat to be a bit more tactical, but because its active it seems to mostly involve turn-and-circle strafing most enemies and DPSing them down while avoiding being hit.  This isn't what I expected from an RPG, even an active one.  Theres not much back-and-forth, HP is there to make up for the mistakes you make or if you encounter too many enemies to easily achieve hit and run tactics.  Or for if you fall afoul of a trap.  Theres not much in the way of resource management, and the best solution is to backtrack to full-heal savepoint crystals for even minor wounds because the only reason to expend consumable resources is in dire emergencies and never to cover normal mistakes.  Character progression (from what I remember researching) seemed prone to the trap of making a useless build.  Its been awhile, so I could be wrong here and dismiss this if I am.Speaking of traps, I really dont like the puzzle and trap mechanics in this game.  Some of the puzzles are fairly obtuse, which could be okay except that you can end up just wandering forever not seeing a switch on a wall or the like if you dont look up a guide.  This is just true of some genres, even ones I love like point and click adventures, but the solution basically spoils part of the game.  In P&C games the puzzles are tied to a story.  A lot of traps aren't great because they're kind of like being exposed to a jumpscare.  'Haha, got you!'  Sometimes you die, sometimes you backtrack to a save crystal because you took somewhere between 1 to 99% damage, sometimes you backtrack because the trap diverted you, etc.  A lot of it is just trial and error, some of it is gotchas, but it never really felt clever or fun to me.Story is also lacking from what I saw.  Your characters have no backstory and you occasionally receive cryptic telepathic messages about a mysterious person who knows the mysterious truth behing the mysterious dungeon you are trapped in.  I didnt get far enough to figure it out, but I assume its just a premise to tie the gameplay together.  That can be okay, but I just didnt personally enjoy the story.A lot of people liked the game, but do your research first.  I like RPGs and have played them all my life, but this one wasn't  for me.

content:
er 28, 2016
												This is a great modern game that succeeds in giving players a old school dungeon crawler feel while still manages to be creative.The Good:1) "With a 95% positive rating, its likely you will enjoy this game." - Captain Obvious.2) Good Graphcis3) Good Music4) Good RPG experience5) Creative and smart puzzles/riddles. What's a good dungeon crawler game if it didn't have good dungeon designs?6) Old school mode. I never had a chance to unds how playing a game while having to draw my own map was like. No longer the case with this game.7) Extras. Above sound track and concept art, there's actually reading material and quite abit of lore builing. Love the world map and descriptions of each races etc.8) Good combat, a true test of gaming dexterity and skill. 8a) You will soon realise timing is crucial. If you timed your attacks well enough you can put enemies in a partial stun-lock. consider enemy recovery time and your characters' cooldown etc. Very fun to learn how to exploit this.8b) I'll say that the combat is clumsy in a good way. You have to draw complicated runes to cast powerful spells. Potions can only be used from inventory. Weapons must be changed in inventory and dragging the icon. Attacks will only be made by right clicking on the correct location where the images of your weapons are. Your archer will have to swap between crossbow+quarrel and bow+arrow (thats 2 item swaps which takes alot of time). You have to pay attention to enemies' attacks and movement and then move your party accordinly to dodge attacks. All of that and much more are all in real time. No pause of combat. Opening maps and inventory only makes you open to enemy attacks instead of pausing the whole game or combat. All these makes this game awesome.The Bad:1) Story suck.. I don't actually mind since good story are usually more of a bonus. But the most rememebered and talked about games are the ones with great story. So I find this more a pity than anything else.2) Replay value. Kinda low since any difference in a 2nd try would be too little to justify the trouble to have to do the entire adventure all over again... Toorum mode was interesting though.All in all, good game sold at a low price. You're totally losing out if you gave this game a miss.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2015
												Legend of Grimrock is best summarized in its manual: "The game features dungeon exploration, puzzles, secrets, combat, magic and role playing elements."The game's enjoyment comes from navigating the dungeon, avoiding traps, finding hidden switches and looting treasures. Combat is fairly simple, it consists of avoiding attacks by maneuvering around your adversaries, and the only tactical element is picking a place with enough room to do so (also being mindful of pits and other enemies cornering you). All in all combat is just another puzzle element in this game, the experience points and skills you earn a different form of reward.The game's overall difficulty is rather involved but lenient, it requires patience and attention to detail. There is a lot of diversity in puzzles, I've never come across two identical ones. They will test your memory, reflexes, and creativity, so you are bound to appreciate some of them while finding other tedious or unremarkable. Only in two instances did I get stuck. On the other hand the designers can be quite devious at times when it comes to traps, especially towards the end of the game. Some might find it frustrating, but I see it rather as playfulness and awareness of the exploits used in that genre of games.The game's visual and sound design, while polished, lacks diversity. Being quite lengthy (20-30 hours depending on difficulty/old school mode settings), but only comprised of two different kinds of environment (with a third on the tiny last two levels), the game can seem quite bleak after a while. The loot also becomes more scarce and less exciting, supplies more numerous, making it less rewarding to search for secrets. The lack of new enemies and puzzle elements adds to an overall fatigue building up until the two bottom floors. The final boss requires mobility and precision, also some ingenuity but most of all calm. It reinvigorated my enjoyment of the game, as the end fight was unexpectedly innovative.

content:
er 29, 2015
												LoG is a grid style dungeon crawler that has revived the genre from its dying lineage from such games like 80's Dungeon Master.  This 13 floor, heavy puzzled, medium combat gameplay title does an excellent job at presenting new comers and old to the maze like dungeon of the Mountain of Grimrock.  Most of the puzzles work around pushing lose stones that protrude out from the walls and the combat style is of dancing around in a grid motion around the enemy.  There is no tank and spank strategy here unless playing on easy difficulty.The game will take 20+ hours to complete depending on whether or not you spend the time to do the puzzles and/or find all the missing treasures that can be used for achievements or just upgrading you characters with better equipment.  The graphics are well done and the animation is quite well too.  There is an unlockable character that you must find in the dungeon which will let you run a new game once found with all new traits that will be different compared to the games regular 4 person party you've played with.  If enjoyed this alone is great replay value that extends the life even further to this gem.Looking for a great grid style dungeon crawler look no further to The Legend of Grimrock!

content:
ry 16, 2014
												The level design, enemy placement, and especially the puzzles are all, by and large, wonderfully crafted. There are a few instances where the "traps" seem more unfair than clever, but that hardly tarnishes what is otherwise a terrific experience. You'll be hard-pressed to find a modern game like Legend of Grimrock any time soon, but with a game of this quality, you won't need one.In a way, The Legend of Grimrock is a lot like Dark Souls. The game rewards calculated, meticulous play and any severe injuries or deaths are likely a result of not taking in your surroundings. There are a lot of ways to die in Grimrock and if you're not paying attention, taking the time to search out better gear and learn to craft potions, you're going to have a difficult time with it. However, there's a great feeling of accomplishment as you traverse each floor, defeating powerful monsters and figuring out puzzle solutions on your own.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2013
												Every now and then there comes a game that tries to revisit genres that have fallen by the wayside as the video game industry continues to change and grow. Dungeon crawler games, for the most part, happen to be one of those genres. So when I first saw images for Legend of Grimrock I couldn’t help but be excited.When I was a kid I spent a lot of time playing the old dungeon crawler games. I still vividly remember such titles as Dungeon Master and Dungeon Master II: The Legend of Skullkeep. Given how much time I spent playing those games, and loving every minute of it, I was hoping that this new game would live up to the games in whose footsteps it was following.I’ll tell you right now, I have not been disappointed.Legend of Grimrock is everything it is supposed to be. It is an old-style dungeon crawler modernized for today’s gaming world. While such a game can be limited in terms of graphics and art style, Almost Human, the indie developer behind the title, has executed it perfectly. The game looks great and the various creatures’ appearances are fantastic given the limits of the genre.Read the rest of my review at Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-legend-of-grimrock/

content:
4, 2014
												This is a great tribute to the first person RPG's of yesteryear, such as Dungeon Master and the Eye of the Beholder series.  Combat is difficult, and requires careful maneuvering as well as the right builds for your characters.  Some of the puzzles are fiendishly difficult, but all of them are fair, and I only had to go searching for solutions a couple of times on my first play through.Graphically, the game does what it sets out to do very well, though the tile sets and enemy types are all limited.  Even so, the look of the game, combined with what turns out to be a surprisingly good sound track add to the intense atmosphere of the whole experience.  The whole thing gives off an almost 'survival horror meets fantasy rpg' hybrid, and one that I greatly enjoyed.  I recommend it highly.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2016
												This game is a tile-based hack n' slash with very rudimentary role-playing elements. The closest thing I could compare it to is Might and Magic X, although this game is not turn based and has no emphasis on story. You create and control four characters, moving on a tile, and fight stuff/solve puzzles. You get 2 characters in the front row that can swing melee and get hit by melee, and two in the back that can't reach or be reached. Let me jump right in to the gameplay. I did not like the combat in this game because it is what I like to call "very clicky". Since the game is not turn-based, you have to fight monsters in real time. Basically the combat involves clicking on all of your character's weapon icons to make them swing or shoot at the enemy, then waiting for the attack to come off cooldown so you can use it again. You can get fancy and swap out characters that are getting hurt too badly with characters in the back, ostensibly "tag teaming them". You can also abuse the fact that you can move on tiles faster than the enemies can, out flanking and out maneuvering them so that they can't hit you but you can hit them. This is pretty much the limit of what you can do in combat. It makes the game feel rather actiony and twitchy, rather than tactical. The latter technique just feels rather abusive and cheesey which made it not fun for me to do. However, I quickly found out that you need to do this in order to not take too much damage. Now, it's true that you can cast spells in combat to make things a little more interesting, but the spellcasting system is rather flawed as well. You're basically tracing patterns and clicking certain rune buttons that comprise a "formula" for the spell. But since you're doing this in real time, it's very clunky and awkward to do. It becomes more of a clicky reflex thing (how fast can you do it!) than a tactical or roleplaying thing. Something like this could be really cool in a turn-based game, where you're depending on the character's skill and not your own hand speed as the player. Overall this would make a more RPG friendly experience. The second bad thing about the gameplay is that the puzzles are extremely contrived. The very first one I encountered was solved by clicking a tiny section of wall that looked no different than any other section of wall. I found it only because I clicked literally everywhere on screen for several minutes and got lucky. I guess this is the gameplay?! You'll probably have to look up guides if you play this. I don't see why they can't put some kind of clue or hint or make the section of the wall look suspiciously different. This would make the puzzles at least engaging and make the player feel smart for figuring it out. So, what about the ruleset and character progression? Well, I actually can't say too much about the rule system. That's because the game doesn't explain how different stats are being calculated. At the character creation screen, you put points in four ability scores that are well defined as to what things they increase. The game even shows a stat block next to the ability scores which changes to reflect the ability scores as you mess with them. The problem is, we don't know what a lot of this stuff does, how it's calculated, or even what a "good" score would be. For example, we know dexterity increases accuracy, but "accuracy" isn't defined at all. Sure, it's obvious it has something to do with hit chance, but we don't know how attack rolls are claculated in this game so we're not really making an informed decision here. This system could be a lot more transparent. Moreover, you also buy skill points. Mousing over a skill tree shows the first few bonuses you get from increasing that skill, but not the whole chart. So again, you don't really know what it is that you're choosing. The spell skills (earth, fire, water, air) don't even define what type of spells that tree covers! It would be awesome if it showed brief explanation of what kinds of things to expect in each tree, followed by two examples of earth spells. But because the game doesn't do that, you're going in blind again. This neccessitates that you're going to end up picking some combination of skills and stats that don't work. This game is very trial-by-error type of gameplay. I myself made a minotaur tank who focused on large hit point pools for defense and massive strength for big damage output, and he got massacred right away which of course ended up being a TPK. So you can forget about playing the character you WANT to play. Instead you'll be playing the character the developers want you to play. My minotaur example helps me transition to the next point: there is extreme imbalance in the stats in this game. From personal experience of dying so much when using certain stats, as well as looking up guides online, I found out the truth about the system. Strength is completely awful for a melee character. "What! That's completely counter-inuitive!" Exactly. Turns out, the damage bonus provided by high strength doesn't scale at all and isn't enough enough to actually change how many hits it takes to kill and enemy. Doh. Stamina is likewise bad for a tank, it's just better to focus on evading damage and protection (armor). Again, counter-intuitive. Turns out the only stat that really matters for anyone who isn't a mage is Dexterity. Likewise, a lot of the feats in the game are totally useless and there are like 2 good ones that you should just take on every character. Lastly, everything in this game is incremental. None of the skills or feats really make your characters pop out as unique or change the way you approach combat. The game would have benefitted from some really colorful Fallout style feats. Summary: This game is an optimization, trial and error, incremental hack n' slash lacking any depth or unique character progression. The combat is action based and clicky. I would reccomend this to an action gamer who likes to just look up guides and isn't interested in roleplaying.

												I wasn't really sure if this type of game would really be something I'd enjoy, but now that I've completed my first playthrough I can say I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The combat is well designed and varied, and it is simple enough for anyone to pick up, but there's still a surprising amount of depth to it as well. The puzzles were also very well done, never feeling illogical or unfair. However, they were still challenging enough that completing them always felt rewarding. Overall, Legend of Grimrock is a great game that takes an old formula not really seen in video games these days, and creates something unique from it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
13, 2012
												This game is great! It is a spiritual sequel to the old game Dungeon Master from the 80s, but with modern graphics and updates like better AI and an automap. If you like dungeon crawls, get it. You wont be disappointed.Its a dungeon crawl like Eye of the Beholder. Graphics are very nice with the traditional square tunnels and chains hanging on the walls, moss ect. Theres alos the occasioanl cool statue or art on the walls as well. Step, turn, strafe and so forth. The puzzles ramp up in difficulty nicely. They are the typical find keys, secret buttons, pull levers in order, run quickly, and so forth. But defintely not stale. Theres also some interesting and unique ones too.  Combat is heavily reliant on the step dance just to survive, a feature I'm not too thrilled about. Unless youre a minmaxer, going toe to toe with an enemy of the appropriate level (on Normal) is not recommended. Youre going to be freezing the enemy and/or dancing all over the place if you want to stay alive. The enemies hit hard. I would say that this is the games major flaw, as I'm way more of a fan of toe to toe melee than swinging and running all over the place till the enemy dies. Its too bad cuz the AI is nice for a square based dungeon crawler. The enemies will actually try and sneak up on you.DMs levelling system was better too. In LoG, theres 4 races and 3 classes. Minotaur, human, lizardman, and insectoid, and mage, rogue and fighter. Once you pick, you're that class. Fighters cant learn magic, and mages cant fight (or seem to do much of anything). And you get XP, just like typical RPGs. Contrast that with DMs "practice a skill and level in that class" style and it just seems...lesser. Also, the game really lends itself to specialization. Pick 1 weapon, 1 magic school. Jack of all trading as far as class skills seems to really hurt in the late game. The sounds and music are nice, typically dungeon-y without being too intrusive. There really isnt too much of a plot in the main game, but thats not why you're here. You're here for the awesome exploration, wondering whats around the corner and seeing if your condemned prisoners will ever win their freedom.All in all a great game and definitely worth picking up for any dungeon/RPG fan. Theres a custom dungeon I have, not sure if I d/led it or it was installed in a patch. Its really great. Uses the same assets, but theres a lot added. For instance, theres way more story. Your character actually speaks to his/her self and when you find more party members, you can chat with them. And you only design one char, picking from the 4 races, but also 4 classes, each with 4 subclasses all slightly different.

content:
er 17, 2014
												Excellent dungeon crawler, it brings together nice visuals with classic gameplay. Reminded me of Portal but with a D&D twist.+Graphics, dungeons, and monsters all look great.+3 classes to choose from (Fighter/Mage/Rogue), each with different skills+Create your own party of 4 characters, even import portraits if you like (takes a little know-how)+A decent variety of skill choices and couple weapon choices per class, with adaptability through leveling+Story and puzzle elements blend together well, some challenging puzzles+Unique spellcasting system using runes like a combination lock+Lots of secrets to uncover and feel rewarded with both equipment and achievements+Probably the most impressive part is that it comes with a dungeon editor - play others' or make your own!-Few default portrait choices for characters-No animations or models for your characters themselves, no voiced dialogue-No cross-classing for any skills/abilities-No shops or salvage system makes looting feel pointless/lackluster at times-Availability of some items unnecessarily punishes some skill choices-Spell system can become more of a chore in combat as the game goes on

content:
er 11, 2016
												The first levels are thrilling. It was my childhood's "Eye of the Beholder" all over again, oh boy! Then the flaws started to creep out. First, as you progress you'll find out that dancing around is a necessity to survive battles. No matter how good your builds are, you characters just can't take hits. That's so hugely silly. Just picture that party of four misfits madly sidestepping around.Which brings us to the stats system. Some attributes' effects are nonsensical and unbalanced. As a result, optimal builds are ridiculous. End game heavy armor on a minotaur will never equal in survivability to puny rogue with evade investement. Heavy axes never equal the devastating power of thrown weapons on a minotaur with nil investment in dexterity.Lastly, the puzzles are obtuse, arbitrary and frustrating.I don't really understand all the glowing reviews. I'm still hoping to find a good old enjoyable dungeon crawler.

												Classic D&D squares! Heavy class based characters! Dice rolling!LoG is basically D&D on screen. You move according to the squares on the floor, so basically in only predetermined steps. Enemies will also move the same as you. Game tends to be puzzle heavy. Every puzzle, is aquainted with a scroll giving a hint towards solving it. Uses Steam Workshop. Music is outstanding. Would kill aga... err play again.

content:
20, 2014
												8/10Fans of oldschool dungeon crawler games will most probably love Legend of Grimrock, as it is an extremely well done dungeon crawler game.While the game only has 3 classes, the different choices in skills make it possible to have multiple builds for each class - thus, there are multiple choices for how to build each of your 4 characters.Combat is specially good in this game because, although the party can stand still and fight one monster, movement can be used to an advantage and, sometimes, it must be used, which adds to the level of challenge of the game. Managing items - weight, ammount and which items are or will be useful or not - is also a challenge by itself.Multiple secrets in each level - and also in the game itself - add a LOT to the game.The game, however, lacks in variety, both in items and enemies. There's little variation between equipment beyond their base values, with a few exceptions of weapons with special effects, and enemies repeat a lot throughout the levels.Leveling up is also somewhat limited - I had the impression that I could get to the end of the game having one character max one skill while also keeping one or two other skills at somewhat decent levels, but I couldn't. And, many times, focusing entirely in one skill is not as good as it seems.The biggest issue I had with the game was the last fight, mostly because it seemed badly designed to me. It's hard to explain without spoiling the fight, but I think people who have finished the game might understand why.Despite its downsides, it's still an amazing game - and the level editor also adds a lot to the game, with some really interesting potential from the player-created levels I've seen.

												Having played 'Dungeon Master' back in the early 90's, I was delighted to see a game based on that style but with modern graphics. So, when the game came on sale I instantly bought it. So, what did I think?A really big WELL DONE! It takes me back to my childhood, playing Dungeon Master and other titles like it with my dad. The nostalgia instantly washed over me, bathing me in that happy feeling. The game is simple in its execution and layout, but does employ various puzzles the deeper you travel into the game, making you think. Combat is good and easy to manage.There is an absence of speech in the game. By that I mean that the four prisoners you command do not engage with each other or say anything. The enemies don't seem to either. Not a problem as it's not that kind of game but at times when the only sound is your footsteps it can get boring. This may have worked twenty years ago but not now in 2015.All in all a great game and a great homage to those early dungeon crawlers.7/10

content:
5, 2015
												If I could describe Legend of Grimrock in one word, it would be grueling. Yet this isn't necessarily a negative. This a constant trek through a single dungeon, with little respite or change in scenery. You constantly have to worry about health, energy and food while fighting enemies, evading traps and solving puzzles. But it feels rewarding in a way. You really need to pay attention and work out scenarios to go foward. Though an obstacle may seem impossible at first: an unbeatable enemy encounter or an unsolvable puzzle, all you gotta do is step back, prepare and use quick wits to get past it. Time and time again you'll pull through in the search of the next floor or secret loot. The controls are a little awkward at first, especially the rune-based magic system, but I feel it's part of the charm. The combat is simple, but requires you to be quick and composed while paying attention to enemy patterns. The puzzles do a lot with very little, simple switches and floor pads are used to create some clever riddles without delving into Myst or La-Mulana tier arcanery. The biggest drawback would be the low production values, due to the small developer. There are only 3 tilesets for the dungeon, one of which you barely see. The main menu theme is great, but the actual game has mostly one ambient track, which is effective for building atmosphere but can get tiring after awhile. Overall, LoG is a great game for those wanting a tribute to the old school dungeon crawlers like Eye of the Beholder, or anyone wanting a somewhat challenging change of pace.

												Pretty fun!  It's an old school tile based dungeon crawler where you customize a party of four adventurers and kill monsters and find loot.  My only complaint would be that it's a little bit simplistic, in the combat and loot departments.  Also that you don't nearly level up enough.  I didn't max out a single skill, even on my fighters who really only put points into armor and their one weapon.

content:
9, 2015
A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock: Fun Old School Dungeon Crawling With A Creepy AtmosphereGenre: 1st Person Old School Dungeon Crawling RPG. Developed and Published by: Almost Human GamesPlatform: Windows, MacOSX and LinuxBusiness Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsLegend of Grimrock (LoG) is a RPG dungeon crawling adventure. It mixes old-school dungeon crawling with modern graphics and design. It focuses on survival and puzzle solving with some combat. Combat and travel is executed on a grid-based system. You and the enemies move forwards, backwards and sides in squares, an old-school throwback.The StoryThe game takes place in a world known only as The Northern Realms. You play as a group of four prisoners of varying races. These four prisoners have been sentenced for their crimes against the King by "The Court". Your sentence is to be thrown into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock and once at the bottom of the pit, you'll be pardoned of your crimes. The only problem is, no one has survived the depths of Mount Grimrock. Can you survive past the creatures, traps and challenges before you? Well, your going to find out soon enough. Your mission is to do just that. You have to find out a way out of the place. Solve the puzzles, unlock the mysteries of Grimrock and survive. You're also being talked to in your dreams by someone...or something. The story is mostly told in dream sequences and scrolls left lying around in the dungeons. From these scrolls, you'll get clues to what's going on in the depths of Mount Grimrock as well as vague hints about the outside world.Combat and PuzzlesLoG features combat, puzzle & riddle solving, RPG elements and exploration. Combat is tile based and in real time. Since it has this tile movement, your enemies must be directly facing you to attack. They're unable to attack at a diagonal from you. The combat system is a bit quirky and wonky. It takes quite a bit of practice to get used to fighting on what is essentially squares and being able to only face four directions. Not only that, it's in real-time, so creatures may come out of no where and take you by surprise. For the most part, the combat doesn't have a lot of depth but it's surprisingly enjoyable. Since you can't take too many direct hits from enemies, as they hit like a truck, most of the time will be spent sidestepping around enemies and poking them to death with spells and weapon swipes. This also means that getting caught in a surrounded by creatures will lead to a quick death. This can be a frustrating part of the game and it can happen almost too many times for comfort. However, it usually felt like I had gotten myself in that bad situation, not the game. So, you need to be very self-aware of your surroundings and survive as best you can. Fortunately, there's a finite amount of creatures on every level. Once you kill them all, you're given free reign to walk around and explore the level on your own terms. Still, I will say that the combat system stands on a razor's edge. At times it can be far too easy and others it can be far too frustrating. This is the type of system that if it strays just a little, will cease to be enjoyable. There's also has a variety of different puzzles and riddles you must solve to not only advance but to find hidden secrets. Switches, levers, camouflaged buttons, defeating the right enemies or finding keys are all items used to impede your forward progress. Still, figuring it out is what I enjoy most about LoG. Even if it is tempting to use the Internet or Steam guides to solve a particularly tricky puzzle. (Which I did do that a couple of times. I know, I know). LoG definitely shines when it's about puzzles and less so when you're in combat. So, if you aren't a fan of puzzles, then you might not enjoy LoG that much. VisualsThis game is a looker. Everything has a fidelity and crispness that you wouldn't expect out of such an indie project. The creature designs and animations are very well done. It was impressive how lifelike some of the attacking creatures looked when they attacked. Even if a lot of the animations are reused, I still think of these creatures being real, of having substance. The lighting system in this game is excellent, with shadows playing lifelike over the walls and creatures as you move about. It all sells the experience of being in a dark, underground dungeon.Audio and AtmosphereWhile LoG has an awesome intro menu song that pumps you up for action, there isn't any music in the game itself. Instead, the game has whistling, quiet winds and other sound elements that sell the atmosphere of LoG. This sense that you're in an underground dungeon that is out to kill you. That every step forward is both a step towards ultimate freedom and possible death. Just to really sink it in, they let you hear the footsteps of potential enemies nearby. As though at any time, they might pop out of the wall and split you in two. But you wanna know the best part? There are some enemies that stand perfectly still until it's much too late. Think on that for a while.PC Settings and MoreLoG comes with all the graphics, audio and keybinding settings you'll need. Resolution options are plentiful and it can display in fullscreen, windowed borderless and windowed. V-sync has a enabled/disabled setting. Texture resolution, filtering, shadow quality and SSAO quality have low-medium-high sliders. There's also separate audio sliders with mute options. Autosave can be turned on/off with other minor settings included as well. Keyboard controls can be completely configured if needed. You can also enable a touchscreen/tablet mode which is pretty neat. There is no FOV slider and this is probably intentional for game balance. I can't say for certain if the FoV is fine or not but I think the grid-based movement will prevent any motion sickness from becoming an issue. It should be noted that Steam cloud isn't enabled for LoG. Final ThoughtsI really enjoyed exploring through the depths of Mount Grimrock. The creepy atmosphere is ever present as you crawl through empty halls expecting danger to popout at any second. The combat is pretty good as well but it can easily tip towards too easy or too frustrating. Legend of Grimrock was an unexpected treat and pleasure for me to play through. It isn't often that I find a game that just clicks with me like this one did. While a few of the puzzles were a bit of a hair-pullers, some of the riddles moreso, I didn't feel like they were too opaque or difficult to figure out. Though it's really tempting to just use the internet or Steam guides to get all the answers. Even so, there's 20 hours of content to enjoy. Side note: Legend of Grimrock was one of my favorite games of 2012. Read the full, unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com] A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock 2. The Island of Broken Bones and Death TrapsRead the notes on this updated review[wp.me]

content:
20, 2014
												8/10Fans of oldschool dungeon crawler games will most probably love Legend of Grimrock, as it is an extremely well done dungeon crawler game.While the game only has 3 classes, the different choices in skills make it possible to have multiple builds for each class - thus, there are multiple choices for how to build each of your 4 characters.Combat is specially good in this game because, although the party can stand still and fight one monster, movement can be used to an advantage and, sometimes, it must be used, which adds to the level of challenge of the game. Managing items - weight, ammount and which items are or will be useful or not - is also a challenge by itself.Multiple secrets in each level - and also in the game itself - add a LOT to the game.The game, however, lacks in variety, both in items and enemies. There's little variation between equipment beyond their base values, with a few exceptions of weapons with special effects, and enemies repeat a lot throughout the levels.Leveling up is also somewhat limited - I had the impression that I could get to the end of the game having one character max one skill while also keeping one or two other skills at somewhat decent levels, but I couldn't. And, many times, focusing entirely in one skill is not as good as it seems.The biggest issue I had with the game was the last fight, mostly because it seemed badly designed to me. It's hard to explain without spoiling the fight, but I think people who have finished the game might understand why.Despite its downsides, it's still an amazing game - and the level editor also adds a lot to the game, with some really interesting potential from the player-created levels I've seen.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
												If I could describe Legend of Grimrock in one word, it would be grueling. Yet this isn't necessarily a negative. This a constant trek through a single dungeon, with little respite or change in scenery. You constantly have to worry about health, energy and food while fighting enemies, evading traps and solving puzzles. But it feels rewarding in a way. You really need to pay attention and work out scenarios to go foward. Though an obstacle may seem impossible at first: an unbeatable enemy encounter or an unsolvable puzzle, all you gotta do is step back, prepare and use quick wits to get past it. Time and time again you'll pull through in the search of the next floor or secret loot. The controls are a little awkward at first, especially the rune-based magic system, but I feel it's part of the charm. The combat is simple, but requires you to be quick and composed while paying attention to enemy patterns. The puzzles do a lot with very little, simple switches and floor pads are used to create some clever riddles without delving into Myst or La-Mulana tier arcanery. The biggest drawback would be the low production values, due to the small developer. There are only 3 tilesets for the dungeon, one of which you barely see. The main menu theme is great, but the actual game has mostly one ambient track, which is effective for building atmosphere but can get tiring after awhile. Overall, LoG is a great game for those wanting a tribute to the old school dungeon crawlers like Eye of the Beholder, or anyone wanting a somewhat challenging change of pace.

content:
ry 23, 2013
												Very good for classic gamers. If you ever played Eye of the Beholder or Lands of Lore, you'll feel right at home. :)The premise is similar: here, you have a grid-based first person RPG with real time battles. You control 4 characters, 2 in the front row and 2 in the back, and explore a huge dungeon full of monsters and puzzles. Its VERY similar to the first Eye of the Beholder, but with a better interface and an automap feature (that can be disabled, if you feel like it).The graphics are great, the enemies are varied and the challenge is quite high. And the puzzles... Ahh, those can range from "I had to think a little" to "WHAT THE HELL DO I DO HERE?!?!". And believe-me: they are FUN, and give a feeling of accomplishment when you finally solve them. The sound effects are great, with realistic ambient effects that give a nice scary mood to the dungeon crawling. The only issue I have is that the game doesn't have music. But thats not a BIG issue (EoB  also didn't have music. ;) ).Anyway, this is one amazing game. Can be frustrating if you don't like puzzles too much, and the battle system can become repetitive after a few hours. But hey, its an amazing game that can take more than 20 hours to beat, and you can even download usermade dungeons to make the playtime even longer.This game is very recommended. ^^

content:
, 2015
												Having played 'Dungeon Master' back in the early 90's, I was delighted to see a game based on that style but with modern graphics. So, when the game came on sale I instantly bought it. So, what did I think?A really big WELL DONE! It takes me back to my childhood, playing Dungeon Master and other titles like it with my dad. The nostalgia instantly washed over me, bathing me in that happy feeling. The game is simple in its execution and layout, but does employ various puzzles the deeper you travel into the game, making you think. Combat is good and easy to manage.There is an absence of speech in the game. By that I mean that the four prisoners you command do not engage with each other or say anything. The enemies don't seem to either. Not a problem as it's not that kind of game but at times when the only sound is your footsteps it can get boring. This may have worked twenty years ago but not now in 2015.All in all a great game and a great homage to those early dungeon crawlers.7/10

9, 2015
A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock: Fun Old School Dungeon Crawling With A Creepy AtmosphereGenre: 1st Person Old School Dungeon Crawling RPG. Developed and Published by: Almost Human GamesPlatform: Windows, MacOSX and LinuxBusiness Model: Base Game.Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsLegend of Grimrock (LoG) is a RPG dungeon crawling adventure. It mixes old-school dungeon crawling with modern graphics and design. It focuses on survival and puzzle solving with some combat. Combat and travel is executed on a grid-based system. You and the enemies move forwards, backwards and sides in squares, an old-school throwback.The StoryThe game takes place in a world known only as The Northern Realms. You play as a group of four prisoners of varying races. These four prisoners have been sentenced for their crimes against the King by "The Court". Your sentence is to be thrown into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock and once at the bottom of the pit, you'll be pardoned of your crimes. The only problem is, no one has survived the depths of Mount Grimrock. Can you survive past the creatures, traps and challenges before you? Well, your going to find out soon enough. Your mission is to do just that. You have to find out a way out of the place. Solve the puzzles, unlock the mysteries of Grimrock and survive. You're also being talked to in your dreams by someone...or something. The story is mostly told in dream sequences and scrolls left lying around in the dungeons. From these scrolls, you'll get clues to what's going on in the depths of Mount Grimrock as well as vague hints about the outside world.Combat and PuzzlesLoG features combat, puzzle & riddle solving, RPG elements and exploration. Combat is tile based and in real time. Since it has this tile movement, your enemies must be directly facing you to attack. They're unable to attack at a diagonal from you. The combat system is a bit quirky and wonky. It takes quite a bit of practice to get used to fighting on what is essentially squares and being able to only face four directions. Not only that, it's in real-time, so creatures may come out of no where and take you by surprise. For the most part, the combat doesn't have a lot of depth but it's surprisingly enjoyable. Since you can't take too many direct hits from enemies, as they hit like a truck, most of the time will be spent sidestepping around enemies and poking them to death with spells and weapon swipes. This also means that getting caught in a surrounded by creatures will lead to a quick death. This can be a frustrating part of the game and it can happen almost too many times for comfort. However, it usually felt like I had gotten myself in that bad situation, not the game. So, you need to be very self-aware of your surroundings and survive as best you can. Fortunately, there's a finite amount of creatures on every level. Once you kill them all, you're given free reign to walk around and explore the level on your own terms. Still, I will say that the combat system stands on a razor's edge. At times it can be far too easy and others it can be far too frustrating. This is the type of system that if it strays just a little, will cease to be enjoyable. There's also has a variety of different puzzles and riddles you must solve to not only advance but to find hidden secrets. Switches, levers, camouflaged buttons, defeating the right enemies or finding keys are all items used to impede your forward progress. Still, figuring it out is what I enjoy most about LoG. Even if it is tempting to use the Internet or Steam guides to solve a particularly tricky puzzle. (Which I did do that a couple of times. I know, I know). LoG definitely shines when it's about puzzles and less so when you're in combat. So, if you aren't a fan of puzzles, then you might not enjoy LoG that much. VisualsThis game is a looker. Everything has a fidelity and crispness that you wouldn't expect out of such an indie project. The creature designs and animations are very well done. It was impressive how lifelike some of the attacking creatures looked when they attacked. Even if a lot of the animations are reused, I still think of these creatures being real, of having substance. The lighting system in this game is excellent, with shadows playing lifelike over the walls and creatures as you move about. It all sells the experience of being in a dark, underground dungeon.Audio and AtmosphereWhile LoG has an awesome intro menu song that pumps you up for action, there isn't any music in the game itself. Instead, the game has whistling, quiet winds and other sound elements that sell the atmosphere of LoG. This sense that you're in an underground dungeon that is out to kill you. That every step forward is both a step towards ultimate freedom and possible death. Just to really sink it in, they let you hear the footsteps of potential enemies nearby. As though at any time, they might pop out of the wall and split you in two. But you wanna know the best part? There are some enemies that stand perfectly still until it's much too late. Think on that for a while.PC Settings and MoreLoG comes with all the graphics, audio and keybinding settings you'll need. Resolution options are plentiful and it can display in fullscreen, windowed borderless and windowed. V-sync has a enabled/disabled setting. Texture resolution, filtering, shadow quality and SSAO quality have low-medium-high sliders. There's also separate audio sliders with mute options. Autosave can be turned on/off with other minor settings included as well. Keyboard controls can be completely configured if needed. You can also enable a touchscreen/tablet mode which is pretty neat. There is no FOV slider and this is probably intentional for game balance. I can't say for certain if the FoV is fine or not but I think the grid-based movement will prevent any motion sickness from becoming an issue. It should be noted that Steam cloud isn't enabled for LoG. Final ThoughtsI really enjoyed exploring through the depths of Mount Grimrock. The creepy atmosphere is ever present as you crawl through empty halls expecting danger to popout at any second. The combat is pretty good as well but it can easily tip towards too easy or too frustrating. Legend of Grimrock was an unexpected treat and pleasure for me to play through. It isn't often that I find a game that just clicks with me like this one did. While a few of the puzzles were a bit of a hair-pullers, some of the riddles moreso, I didn't feel like they were too opaque or difficult to figure out. Though it's really tempting to just use the internet or Steam guides to get all the answers. Even so, there's 20 hours of content to enjoy. Side note: Legend of Grimrock was one of my favorite games of 2012. Read the full, unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com] A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock 2. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												This is a first-person RPG in the style of Eye of the Beholder.  The plot is simple but appropriately so.  You are four convicts who have been exiled to Mount Grimrock.  You receive a pardon upon being exiled because nobody makes it down and out of the mountain.  Ever.  This game is an epic dungeon crawl and it knows it.  You need to find light sources or you will die.  You need to find food or you will die.  You need to manage your inventory and weight loads or, yes, you will die.  The game is pretty tough on the normal difficulty and you can ramp it up with a hard mode as well as an old-school mode where you must create your own maps out-of-game.  The itemization, art direction, and music all contribute to an ambiance that other games from top-tier studios would be wise to emulate.  It is not without its flaws.  The combat system is rather clunky and the grid-layout of the game allows many enenmies killed through mechanical exploitation.  The real difficulty is in the carefully crafted puzzles that push the limitations of the grid-based system to new levels of awesome and often require precision movement and perfect timing.  This game goes on sale often but it is worth it at full price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
24, 2012
												What a fun little game this is! It is a very lightweight game which offers a surprising amount of dungeon crawling enjoyment! I think it's beauty lies in it's simplicity - it's basically just a 2D grid environment with 3D perspective graphics. Your party of 4 adventurers take up one tile and can only move one tile at a time either north, south, east or west. Combat is basically hack n slash but there is quite a bit of timing involved and strategy with how you use your 2 'front row' characters who can melee directly as opposed to the 2 'back row' characters who can either use ranged attacks/magic or perks to do melee attacks from afar. But sometimes you might find yourself cornered where monsters surround you and take big bites out of your typically soft back row guys. There are alot of interesting puzzles some of which can drive you mad trying to figure them out! I really also like how food plays into the game (your guys need to eat!) and how items are very scarce.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 9, 2015
												Old-school dungeoncrawler par excellence. Definitely worth a look if your idea of fun involves being thrown in a hole with nothing but your underoos and stabbing your way through dark tunnels full of inexplicable logic puzzle-based security systems with no real goal beyond "survive to the next room."-----After about... what, two years? I haven't been counting... I've finally beaten this game. And I admit with zero shame I used a walkthrough to find all the secrets, as I was going for achievements and the only way you're getting all of them in one playthrough is prior knowledge, a walkthrough, or going through every brick in the dungeon with a fine-tooth comb.There's not much to say that isn't summed up in that opening paragraph. Legend of Grimrock feels like Tomb of Horrors Lite in terms of surviving by the skin of your teeth through dark, miserable corridors specifically designed to make advancing painful, with some truly clever and sadistic puzzles, some more one than the other.Ultimately my only major criticism is that the final boss is quite possibly the most annoying boss in any game I've ever played, mainly because the arena is litered with swarms of minor enemies that serve no purpose but to be mobile walls to keep you from fleeing, and their mere presence in the room feels so arbitrary that I'm almost certain they were lazily tossed in during beta testing when the devs felt the boss was too easy.So yes, rubbish boss, but altogether a fun old-school dungeon crawler. Give it a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
25, 2012
												LoG is an old school RPG that will appeal to gamers who seek a hardcore nostalgia trip. The character creation system is deep, with 4 races, 3 classes, and a dozen skills to choose from. Combat is a strange mix of real time movement on a grid and turn based attacks. But I didnt find it balanced. Get trapped in a corner and death is inevitable. Have room to move and you shouldnt even get hit. Theres no fun but challenging middle ground. The puzzles are intelligent. Its refreshing to play a game that doesnt guide you by the hand. Its more difficult than say, Portal, but the solutions can usually be figured out if youre patient. However I confess to using a guide on four occasions. The story is decent, but honestly the ending is worse than ME3. The length of the game depends on how long you take to solve the puzzles, but even the smartest gamer should get at least 10 hours. Overall, even though I'm critical on some points, I think LoG is worth playing, especially at the low indie price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
, 2012
												People who remember Dungeon Master I / II, Black Crypt, Lands of Lore will enjoy this game for its nostalgic value as well as being a fun game on it's own.  People who've never played those old school games will still like this game for being different, fun, and not always easy.  Puzzles don't all have obvious solutions, enemies don't always fall so quickly, and a simple hole in the floor can put you in worse trouble than the trouble you were running from - or lead to better armor.  Party member options are somewhat limited, choosing skills when leveling up can make things either easier or more difficult for you, and food and torches become precious.  But this all enhances the challenge of the game, there are even modes that don't automap for you and make enemies harder to kill.  Even the instructions won't tell you everything, you have to learn how to find secrets on your own.  But don't worry, you can still save anytime, unless you'd rather limit yourself to the use of saving stones.

ber 30, 2016
												THESE GAMES ARE AMAZINGwhen i was a kid, i was a huge fan of dungeon crawlers. and for the past 10 years i have never found a good dungeon crawler the was like the old classic ones. yes i had diablo, but i wouldnt call that a dungeon crawler. i would call that a dungeon raider cuz in that game you usualy raid dungeons. im talking about grid movement style ones. i couldnt run the old ones on ym pc for some weird reason and i have a pretty good pc. i found out about this game through pro jared and baught both games instantly and i feel i mad a great choice. these games are exacaly what i wanted with1. classic gameplay that feels like the old dungeon crawlers 2. have old options like having the option to have no map so u have to use grid paper so you have a HUGE challenge and makes you feel more in the game actuallly marking and recordin things that u find (but u can turn on the ingame map)3. being able to MAKE YOUR OWN DUNGEONS4. being able to download other dungeons made by fans5. a great modding comunity 6. being able to make your own gameplay items, weapons and enimies (but u cant make them in the actual game but u can make dungeons in the game with the dungeon editor that comes with both games)7. classic party set up like being able to change the postion of your heros and manage their inv while doing anything like in combat you need to switch weapons well you can 8. great and challenging dungeon crawler puzzles that feel like your actually using your smarts to figure them out (especially late in game) and much much moreif your a fan of those classic dungeon crawlers or want to get into themor your just a fan of rpg's then theses are the games that are made for you10/10

												Excellent game which requires you to think otherwise you can not get easily through enemies. You would mostly want attack one enemy at time, as getting surrounded leads to quick death of your 4 heroes. At the start you can choose your own three classes: fighter, rogue & mage and there are also races which make some advantages over others. I let it by default. Game is very similar to old M&M. Movement is chess-like, only step by step. Your party occupies one square, you can get trapped, you need to figure out the way out and solve puzzles (read your puzzle & try to understand its meaning & use instinct for solving). The game is though pretty simple to understand and I can only recommend the game to every RPG player who likes strategy, chess or puzzles.

content:
14, 2016
 Legend of Grimrock My first Dungeon Crawler I've ever played and I have to admit it makes much more fun as I've thought while I saw a little part of a Let's Play. GamePlay: The Game is in 3D but you can only move ion tiles and turn 90° around. (except for the free mouse view)Move: w,a,s,d as you know it from the most games.q,e for turning 90° left or right.Your party is made out of 4 individual made Characters.2 Front Row - advantage: Melee attacks reach the enemies; disadvantage: Take the hits of front attacks.2 Back Row - advantage: Save for front attacks, may get hits from back or side attacks; disadvantage: cannot reach the enemy with melee weapons. (Of course there are some exceptions)You can choose between different breeds which have their own benefits and these players can be signed as: Mage, Warrior, Rogue - to gain skills of their speciality.★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Graphics: Looks in my opinion fairly nice. No complain!★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Story: hmmm... Not really an impressive story. Get thrown into a Mountain and you have to escape...The helping "thing" in the dreams and all the notes of toorum makes it a bit more interesting.★ ★ ★ ☆ ☆ Leveldesign: It is impressive to see that they got 71 secrets on 13 different Levels. I didn't get even 50 at my first playthrough. As I said, Impressive work. Nice riddles...★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Music: Well... the theme Music at the Menu is amazing. <3 But the whole game has no other soundtrack, at least no soundtrack I've heard... Not even the Boss has one and that was a bit disappointing. Still 4 Stars for that amazing Menu Music!★ ★ ★ ★ ☆All in one it was a bunch of fun I had with this Game, even it was sometimes pretty unfair. :<Well... Doesn't matter. This deserven a ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ rating from me. Well done!

content:
1, 2014
												Prepare to die, again and again. 'Legend of Grimrock' is a hardcore RPG even in normal difficulty. Either I made all the wrong choices either your party is always at a (more than slight) disadvantage as you get to higher levels. I've been poisoned and eaten alive by spiders, incinerated by those flying armored mages, and even chewed up by frosty lizards. The devs really want you to suffer in this dungeon that often seems like a dead end as it's almost impossible to fight and defeat more than one enemy at the time. All the fighting is done real time but there are no shortcuts or hotkeys, therefore the computer will always be quicker then you as you will struggle to command the attack with your mouse - especially with the spells that need several inputs : choosing the wand, choosing 1-4 runes, and then pressing on the attack button AGAIN! But most of all the puzzles will drive you crazy: 'The Maze of Madness' will drive you as mad as hell until you can't take it anymore (or find the improbable solution with no hints whatsoever) and the mostly random logic will leave your characters and yourself starving while you bang your head against the wall. The minimalistic nature of the game is classy, but the lack of real meaning to many of the puzzles is frustrating; some are genuinely good and easy to understand thanks to a scroll (the shadow maze for instance), but now I'm currently stuck in an endless hall in level 9. There's probably a hint I'm missing somewhere in the slaughterfest but maybe I'll die before I find it. I might never see the light of day, after all I've been there for over 24h already...Grimrock don't roll, it's a total headbanger!PS: I eventually found the scroll and got to the game's over-the-top goofy conclusion; you have to see it to believe it! Also the level editor is great and relatively easy to use and some of the mods are actuallly way more enjoyable than the original, there's this awesome Mine of Malan Vael and The Tower of Bones that could both easily be official DLCs while we are all waiting for the sequel.

content:
ber 13, 2015
												Proof you don't need a D&D license and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soap opera story. Just make a great game and leave it at that.Grimrock is a modern dungeon crawler that puts age old mechanics to good use. Your goal is very simple. Guide a party through a nasty dungeon while avoiding traps, fighting monsters, collecting better equipment and leveling up.The game is comfortable and easy to play despite the difficulty ramping up after the first few levels. For those who enjoy exploring and getting lost there's an option to switch off the automap. There are secret areas aplenty and some puzzles require a bit of thinking. Most of the time it's enough to just look everywhere and figure out how to make use of things like pressure plates, teleports or timing mechanisms.The enemies are quite cruel and your party will become overmatched pretty quickly. Fortunately it's possible to close gates and block off some areas, and it's not necessary to kill everything. If you must kill things to progress, usually there's a way to make use of the dungeon itself and make it easier.I have played a lot of dungeon crawlers and have liked some of them. Ishar 3 was good though i never finished it. I loved Captive but finished it even less... Albion was interesting, though not exactly a classic example, and neither was Whale's Voyage. Hired Guns was incredible for it's time and hard as hell for good measure. Never could get into Dungeon Master or Eye of the Beholder much, though EoB was ok. Anvil of Dawn was pretty impressive. I think there's a few games i forgot, but anyway...Maybe i'm weak for Hired Guns a bit more but Legend of Grimrock is the most awesome of the bunch!

content:
er 20, 2013
												 Legend of Grimrock is a old school dungeon crawler offering intense combat, puzzles, exploration, and most of all survival. This game actually reminds me of Shining In The Darkness. Legend of Grimrock offers some really neat features like the ability to eat so you won’t starve. This might throw more casual players off the game because you’ll be managing a entire party and you have to make sure each person/thing in your party is well fed, has plenty of health, weapons, armor, and torches before you decide to continue on your descent into this maze like prison that you’re trapped in. The character creator in this game is awesome. It’s very old school like dungeons and dragons. Basically you choose a portrait, decide on what class you want that character to be, then choose their strengths, and traits. No one character will be good at everything so be careful on what you choose. I always have two warriors, a rogue, and a mage in my party and i’m doing pretty good with them.  The way you learn magical spells is by finding them on pieces of paper scattered around the dungeon. These papers will have the correct way for you to cast the spell. You can also randomly try and cast them but when you’re in a fight you really don’t have time to experiment with your spells. As you find weapons and armor throughout the dungeon you’ll be faced with a choice. Who will you give them too? This is what I love about this game. You won’t find enough equipment for everyone and you have to decide who you want to have them. I usually get my warriors set up for battle before anyone else. I gave the bow to my assassin, staff to me mage, axe to my minotaur, and sword and shield to my human/warrior/tank. Combat in this game is also very old schools. You click on your weapon to attack the enemy in front of you and watch as your sword cuts through the enemy. It’s very basic and easy to learn but it’s up to you to strategize and use tactics when you encounter a large group of enemies.   You don’t want to get surrounded in this game and risk losing one of your party members because they will not come back. Once they die they’re gone until you can find a giant sized blue crystal to revive them and that’s not always easy. In order for you to recover some health you can either rest by pressing the R button or by using a health potion that you’ll eventually find. You can also heal with a magic spell but I wouldn’t advise that since it’s not all that useful. The best ways to heal are by resting, or using a healing potion. When you rest your characters will get hungry so you’ll have to feed them. It’s up to you to decide when to rest and if you have enough food to eat when you’re done resting. ugly Graphically Legend of Grimrock is a good looking game. All of the enemies look good, and the dungeon itself is dark, gloomy, and creepy like a dungeon should be. The sound effects, and soundtrack all help build up to the creepiness that the game has. You’re all alone in this place and I think that adds to the tension while I play the game. Legends of Grimrock isn’t all about looting and killing things. It also has some pretty good puzzles for you to figure out in order to advance to a secret area or get to the next area. I’ve been stuck on more then one occasion trying to figure out the clues to the puzzles when the answer was staring me right in the face. Legend of Grimrock is a amazing, old school dungeon crawler that should be experienced by everyone that loves games that does not hold your hand. My final verdict for Legend of Grimrock is a 10/10! This game took me back to the 90′s with it’s play style and hardcore, no hand holding gameplay. The puzzles are a nice change of pace and knowing that the only way to bring your lost party member back to life is by finding a giant blue crystal really appeals to me. It’s old school and a lot of fun. This game is by all counts Legendary and easily earns my recommendation.  For more of my reviews you can find me on drakulus.com and johnheatz.com.

content:
21, 2013
												A classic RPG in the style of Eye of the Beholder and other first-person RPGs from the early '90s. There's about 25 hours of content here, and its all worthwhile. Much of the game involves trap puzzles. There is no grind or repetition here -- your character will progress at a reasonable rate to match the challenges of each level, and each level offers new and interesting challenges. The game has a retro feel with modern graphics, and doesn't drag on forever like many other RPGs. Much of the fun involves hunting for secrets (and there are many).There's essentially no replay value here, but your first playthrough will give you more than your money's worth. There are no unskippable cutscenes to destroy the fun.

content:
9, 2012
												Grimrock keeps you up. It's tough as nails, but it scratches that dungeon crawler itch... That "Eye of the Beholder/Dungeon Master/So many late 80's early 90's games it's hard to count" dungeon crawler itch. And unlike its roguelike cousins, grimrock is a meticulously plotted and paced experience.I'll admit I probably spent more time playing this than was strictly necessary, but I combed every wall for hidden switches, I slashed every tapestry to see if a cubby of treasure hid beneath, in short, Grimrock hid dozens upon dozens of little wonders and I couldn't help but go seek.My only criticism is, I think a new game + would have been amazing. Being able to play through the game again at a harder difficulty with your entire party and all its equipment would've rocked. But other than that...  I loved it. If you like your games difficult and intelligent, your monsters menacing and your character progression rewarding, buy this game.

content:
r 25, 2016
												I liked Legend of Grimrock for what it was (a basic dungeon crawler à la 'Dungeon Master') but for someone looking for a more critical review, I'll list what I missed in the game regarding:Combat: very simplistic and monotonous. It can be described in 5 words: "Sidestep > Turn > Click attack/spell." You won't be doing anything else from the first trash mob till the final boss.Story: There is none.Items: There is not a lot of variety with weapons / armor, it's a pretty flat, straightforward upgrade path. I think they could 've done more here with random itemization à la Diablo 2 to keep things interesting.Again, these were probably deliberate design choices - partly because of budget constraints (nail the basics > bodging experimental stuff) and partly to emulate the old dungeon crawlers with their very basic gameplay. If that's what you're looking for though, LoG delivers.

Definitely the tastiest game I have played in a long time. Mmmmmmmmmmm...

												This game is very well done. Great enemy variety, good graphics, challenging puzzles, spooky atmosphere, a combat system that is basic (except when it comes to magic, in which case, have fun finding all those spell combonations), and a truly amazing level creator which provides infinite replayability via your own creations and those of your friends. Not to mention the amazing one song soundtrack (That menu will be the best menu you've ever listened to, my friend). If you like this style of game, this will be the game of your dreams that you will never get tired of. Otherwise, it's still a fun experience that can at least get you a few hours of gameplay before you get tired of all those spiders and crabs. Even if you only aim to play through the main story once, that's at least fifteen hours of gameplay right there (or so I'm led to believe, I've never beat it; gave up after the fire demons).

content:
r 14, 2014
												Easily a 9/10.Definitely worth the full price.At first I bought this game during a steam sale and forgot about it, but after burning myself out of a couple of other RPGs I noticed I had this game still practically untouched. The combat is fun and interesting, its fast paced enough to keep you on your toes, but slow enough to give you time to do things like brew a potion on the fly or swap out weapons. The controls can take a little getting used to, but its overall simplicity is a godsend in an age of Menus: the RPG. It would not have much replayability if not for the robust steam workshop integration. The game is pretty light on the story and allows you do get right to the heart of this Dungeon-Crawler without worrying too much about the details.Overall an excellent experience.
