content:
9, 2014
												This game is a freaking blast. I've been running just the main dungeon they start you with, not a downloaded one off the workshop, and it is the epitome of classic dungeon simulation. The puzzles are challenging, the combat isn't just point and click, the aesthetic really matches the environment, makes me feel really immersed, and the story is subtle yet intruiging. Gameplay - 9/10 - Really fits it's genre well, quality gameGraphics - 8/10 - The lighting and textures are fantastic, but on one creature I laughed out loud when I saw it, it just looked so silly. Nice to look at though.Story - 7/10 - Despite not really being a story-driven game, the light story shoe-horned in seems to push you forward with a certain sense of uncertainty.Replayability - x/10 - I'd assume playing the first dungeon would be interesting to run multiple times, see how fast you can do the whole thing again, but the true playability comes from the custom-made dungeons, which will add time spent on the game as long as the community keeps making them. Overall - 8.5/10. Great dungeon game.

content:
16, 2012
												Ok, so you remember the old-school first-person dungeon crawlers? It's one of those, and it's excellent.Oh, wait, you said "no"? Oh, well, let me break it down for you. It's an RPG with light story, grid-based movement, puzzles and exploration a-plenty, and monsters intent on ruining your day at every turn. You know The Elder Scrolls? It's not like that. You don't go on quests, you don't visit towns, you don't save the world. You get one massive dungeon that you and your party of four wander through in a ceaseless battle for survival and escape. The game is hard for the modern gamer. It requires careful planning, strategy, and knowing a few things about RPGs (fire wrecks undead, poison is wasted on spiders, etc.), but every battle is rewarding.If you want something old (or something new, depending on your gaming history), grab this. It's incredible, and there's the promise of custom dungeons on the horizon, so you'll have plenty more exploring to do in the future. Good luck.

content:
r 12, 2012
												Do not underestimate this game: it is tough. Even on easy, the puzzles become daunting, the monsters brutal, and your party's resources frighteningly scarce. If you're not careful to level up your characters efficiently right out of the gates you'll find yourself trapped in grinding mode until you're able to progress...but be warned: your food dwindles at an alarming rate and is every bit as elusive as any other form of aid. It's a no-joke type situation, and a person would do well to get into this with the mindset of committing to a hardcore adventure.Nonetheless, I find the challenge a good thing. It's refreshing to have to think in a video game again and quite rewarding when you manage to proceed to another floor. You can spend a huge amount of time playing this game too--plenty of levels, lots of achievements, tons of brain teasing puzzles, plenty of weapons and gear to scavenge and disburse amongst your characters. While not for the faint of heart, this game gets my thumbs-up.

												Great nostalgia factor.  Authentic old school dungeon crawler gameplay with decently modern graphics. content:
ber 23, 2014
												This is a great "old school like" RPG: the already good "campaign" is complemented by the goodness you can find on Steam Workshop, which arguably gives this game more than it's money worth. In this game you control a party of four prisoners in first person, which all move simultaneously along a grid ( which means you can go one square forward/left/right/back at a time, but not diagonally ). The classes available are the classic Warrior, Rogue and Mage. Each character has attributes ( Strength, Dexterity, ... ), skills ( Axes, Air Magic, ... ) and two choosable traits ( perks ) plus racial traits. Combat is real time, and magic is casted by selecting a valid combination or 9 runes.

content:
4, 2014
												A great tribute to oldschool dungeon crawlers (the kind I grew up with in the late 80s and early 90s).  I think it definitely helps to have been a fan of tabletop stuff like D&D and Warhammer (which I'm thankful to my father for, for raising me on) to really appreciate how cool this game is.  It's just as much about strategy and timing as it is hunting for loot.  A nice mix between easy, almost obvious puzzles and puzzles that will have you face-palming in frustration.If you're like me and you were raised on high fantasy, classic computer games and tabletop strategy, the nostalgia factor will be very high.

content:
r 12, 2012
												Do not underestimate this game: it is tough. Even on easy, the puzzles become daunting, the monsters brutal, and your party's resources frighteningly scarce. If you're not careful to level up your characters efficiently right out of the gates you'll find yourself trapped in grinding mode until you're able to progress...but be warned: your food dwindles at an alarming rate and is every bit as elusive as any other form of aid. It's a no-joke type situation, and a person would do well to get into this with the mindset of committing to a hardcore adventure.Nonetheless, I find the challenge a good thing. It's refreshing to have to think in a video game again and quite rewarding when you manage to proceed to another floor. You can spend a huge amount of time playing this game too--plenty of levels, lots of achievements, tons of brain teasing puzzles, plenty of weapons and gear to scavenge and disburse amongst your characters. While not for the faint of heart, this game gets my thumbs-up.

content:
9, 2014
												This game is a freaking blast. I've been running just the main dungeon they start you with, not a downloaded one off the workshop, and it is the epitome of classic dungeon simulation. The puzzles are challenging, the combat isn't just point and click, the aesthetic really matches the environment, makes me feel really immersed, and the story is subtle yet intruiging. Gameplay - 9/10 - Really fits it's genre well, quality gameGraphics - 8/10 - The lighting and textures are fantastic, but on one creature I laughed out loud when I saw it, it just looked so silly. Nice to look at though.Story - 7/10 - Despite not really being a story-driven game, the light story shoe-horned in seems to push you forward with a certain sense of uncertainty.Replayability - x/10 - I'd assume playing the first dungeon would be interesting to run multiple times, see how fast you can do the whole thing again, but the true playability comes from the custom-made dungeons, which will add time spent on the game as long as the community keeps making them. Overall - 8.5/10. Great dungeon game.

r 14, 2014
												Easily a 9/10.Definitely worth the full price.At first I bought this game during a steam sale and forgot about it, but after burning myself out of a couple of other RPGs I noticed I had this game still practically untouched. The combat is fun and interesting, its fast paced enough to keep you on your toes, but slow enough to give you time to do things like brew a potion on the fly or swap out weapons. The controls can take a little getting used to, but its overall simplicity is a godsend in an age of Menus: the RPG. It would not have much replayability if not for the robust steam workshop integration. The game is pretty light on the story and allows you do get right to the heart of this Dungeon-Crawler without worrying too much about the details.Overall an excellent experience.

content:
ry 17, 2016
												This game is amazing, I really like it, I put a few hours into it so far nd I am loving every minute of it. The combat is very well done, and although its turn based, the fact you can move around to avoid damage is very good. Also having the 2 front line characters and 2 back line characters makes it so you can strategically place your characters the way you want. I made to fighters  with one being really tanky and the other one having a bit more damage to go in my front line and a mage and rogue for my back line, and I find it a very good setup. Theres 4 races. Human, Minotaur, Insectoid, and Lizard man, and each has their own strengths and weakness. Human is balanced all around, but isn't the best at one specific class, Minotaur is more tanky, but has low dexterity so they have a low starting hit rate, making them good tanks, Lizard man has high dexterity, but lower strength, making them better rogues, and Insectoid has higher willpower, making them better mages.Of course you don't have to make a character based off their stats. You could for example make a Lizard man fighter that has high dexterity, but lower strength, or a Minotaur rogue that has more health and damage, but hits less,  or all humans for all around classes. It may not be as reccomended, but would work. Also honestly the game allows you to import your own photos, only the specs make up each race, so you could essentially have 4 anime chicks if you really wanted. Overall it is a great game, and is very fun, and addicting. It has great gameplay, great sound deseign with the ambient soundtrack, pretty decent graphics that are pretty enough, but also not too demanding for those that have lower end pcs can play, engaging puzzles and the enviroment is nice, even if it is just a dungeon it really fits the game, and although there isn't much to the story, it is just enough to fit the style of this game. I would highly reccomend this game. 10/10

content:
er 7, 2012
												Legend of Grimrock should be seen as definitely proof that Finns are actually good for something despite their well known insanity, or perhaps because of it.Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the core of the RPG genre. Stat based dungeon crawling. No mouse twitching skills required. No pseudo-choices that have no gameplay effects. No dialog pretending to be grey.This is pure RPG gameplay. You create your party and fight through a dungeon of monsters finding new equipment and leveling up their skills and stats as you go along.Despite the fairly oldschool grid based gameplay it is a pretty game, with good sounds, great exploration, hard to find secrets and frustrating puzzles. The combat might seem simple from the outside but movement will play a major part in the harder battles and particularly on the harder difficulties.If there was something bad to say about this game it was a relatively short main campaign but the addition of Steam Workshop fixed that.A great buy.

content:
7, 2014
LEGEND OF GRIMROCKA first-person dungeon crawler set in a series of underground labyrinths, filled with monsters, puzzles and traps.Rating 7/10A throwback to the early 90s role-playing games like Eye of the Beholder, Ultima Underworld and Stonekeep. Whilst in many ways Legend of Grimrock is a homage to those early games it's worth buying not just for nostalgia but because it's a great game in it's own right.In updating the classic formula they haven't changed much, grid-based movement, advancing one tile at a time with 90 degree turns. The party consists of four different characters spread across three classes, the fighters in the front row and the more vulnerable mage and Rogue in the back row. The two in the front row will deal the most damage and take the most damage via melee combat, the two characters in the back row can use magic and ranged attacks. It's a fine balance and timing is key in order to keep your party alive. Combat suffers from the same limitations as it did in the games Grimrock is trying to re-create, wait for the enemy to enter the tile in front of you before unleashing all of your attacks then back away or strafe sideways before they have a chance to return damage. Rinse and repeat. There are obviously times this strategy doesn't always work such as being surrounded by three or more enemies or backing into a dead end but it's the strategy you'll end up using the most. It worked back in the 90s and it still works now. There is a story loosely attached but it's not really important, this is a dungeon crawler at heart and the fun comes from fighting your way through and solving puzzles in each new level of the dungeon. There are no quests to speak of other than to survive the dungeon. During the game you pick up clues and lore via letters left by a previous prisoner called Toorum, it's a simple but effective way of building up some atmosphere and history to the adventure.It's a bit too easy and a bit too short. I completed the game twice unlocking all achievements, completing my second play through on Hard Boiled and Doin' It Old School and even then I completed it with little effort. Aside from making the game longer I felt it would have benefited from a few NPCs, something Stonekeep did to great effect. It would have broken up the game play a bit and offered something different. However these are fairly minor disappointments to what is otherwise a superb game.Looking forward to Legend of Grimrock 2.

er 28, 2013
												What can I say about Legend of Grimlock... Playing on computers since commodore 64 I have always loved games. One genre that sucked so much of my life away as a kid was dungeon crawlers. Floor after floor of single step adventure, never knowing when something will cross your path. The terror of when something is standing deep in that barely lit hall. Every step followed by theres until the faceoff tells who will step once more. This games has it all wrapped in new beautiful graphics. EVERY thing that I loved, All that I hated. I highly recommend it to any fan of the old dungeon crawler genre. I might even go as far as saying you are doing yourself a disservice by bypassing this one.

												One of my favorite indie gamesA grind based dungeon crawler, aparently based on some old school games ive never played, but if they are anywhere near as good as legend of grimrock ive missed outWithin the game you control a party of 4 characters at the same time and move in first person through square grind based dungeons, the game has a great degree of micromanagement, you use the different attacks of your party members individually, they suffer from different status effects, they all have their own stats and they all suffer from hunger and carrying limitations, not to mention since your characters are set up in a square formation within the square grind you are on attacks from different directions affect different party members, learning to balance all of this is pivotal to successthe dungeons in this game are all well designed with clever puzzles and some nice settings. The combat in the game is for the most part decent, it can get a little boring agaisnt single enemies, since running around em is usually enough, but when multiple enemies are present it becomes really challenging, since you must maneuver the environment skillfully to avoid getting trapped and having your weakest party members killed. Your party members can belong to 4 races and 3 different classes, each with their own characteristics, the mage class is a standout, offering the most interesting and challenging combat of all classes. The game in general is very hard but fair, with only a couple of traps and situations id describe as cheapWhen it comes to graphics, they are somewhat simple but pleasing to the eye, with an adequate amount of detail on screen and a good art direction, its understandably claustrophobic but this goes well with the game's setting and mechanics, i guess one flaw on this regard is the fact we are dealing with the overly familiar middle ages fantasy setting herethe game has a very long campaign, it took me around 19 hours to finish the main campaign and i didnt even find all the secrets, you can start a new game with different party configurations and the game has steam workshop support with over 700 custom dungeons, this thing has some serious replay valuefantastic game overall, my mayor complain is the fact a game like this begs for randomization and yet it has none, it could really benefit for random dungeons with random loot, random spells, random enemies in random locations, but well i guess the game couldnt have these brilliant puzzles otherwise, and the steam workshop support does alleviate this shortcoming a bit﻿

												Proper old school RPG. If you loved EOTB and Dungeon Master then you'll enjoy this one too. Its clearly been made by people who were fans of the originals and its a real work of love. Its managed to keep all the great elements of the early games, lots of puzzles that will keep you occupied and keeping the old combat tactics in place. They've given it lots of attention in terms of the graphics, sound and music, and overall its really well designed and thought through dungeon crawler classic. The dungeon designer looks really straghtforward to use too, and adds a nice additional touch to the package. Heartily recommended, especially for the old-schooler. My score is a ice 9 out of 10

content:
18, 2012
												A fantastic old-school first person dungeon crawler full of hidden passages, complex puzzles, and difficult combat. The graphics and sound design are amazing considering the game is only 600mbs. Most of the music is ambience leading to a calm gameplay experience... until a skeleton rushes around a corner and makes you jump. Old style games like this have a terror of their own with the lighting and sound effects. When your torch goes out, it is pitch black until your characters "eyes" adjust and even then you can barely see. The only real complaint I have is the combat can be frustrating when you get body-blocked into a corner or are simply overpowered because of poor stat placement or equip.If you go into this expecting "Amnesia with swords" instead of "Skyrim without towns" you will have a great experience. Be prepared for a game that wants to beat you down; save often and take map notes because you will need all the help you can get.

content:
6, 2015



YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Legend of Grimrock is a dungeon crawling role playing game with an oldschool heart but a modern execution. A group of prisoners are sentenced to certain death by exiling them to the secluded Mount Grimrock for vile crimes they may or may not have committed. Unbeknownst to their captors, the mountain is riddled with ancient tunnels, dungeons and tombs built by crumbled civilizations long perished now. If they ever wish to see daylight again and reclaim their freedom the ragtag group of prisoners must form a team and descend through the mountain, level by level. - Highly Recommended!

r 12, 2014
												A great and well rounded game that has just the right amout of difficulty and unforgiveness. Reminds me a lot of table top Dungeons and Dragons. My only complaint is there is hardly a punishment for death. When a character dies they can still hold torches and their inventory can still be opened. If I were to change something about this game it would be that dead characters can't hold torches(or provide light in any way) and also make it so either the dead character's inventory becomes locked or their inventory is split up into the other party members. Other than that I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys dungeons and dragons, dungeon crawlers, and even rogue likes. I give it a solid 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
er 1, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is an accessible dungeon crawler with fun and engrossing puzzles; the kind of puzzles that aren't complicated but require a decent understanding of the point-and-click mechanics. Unfortunately most of the underwhelming puzzles require hugging the wall and hunting down hidden wall switches.The RPG mechanics are pretty barebones. The combat consist of mindless clicking and side-stepping. You'll most likely never reach the end level class skills in your first playthough without excessive grinding. The only redeemable aspect of combat is the spellcasting system. In Grimrock, using magic spells require you enter the correct combinations of runes, as if you are dialing them on a keypad. Learning new rune combinations through the scrolls found in the dungeon is always an enjoyable treat. I only beat the main campaign but it took me roughly 10 hours not counted on Steam as my internet connection was down for a period of time. The user submitted workshop dungeons could hypothetically add even more unique playtime with this but I haven't had a clue if they are as good as the main game. Grimrock is well worth the full price by itself, though.One final note is that if you are of faint of heart you might not enjoy this game as it throws you a ton of creepy creatures that run around in the darkness of the dungeon.

content:
er 30, 2013
												One of the first birthdays i can remember, i was given "Dungeons & Dragons: Warriors of the Eternal Sun" for the sega mega drive, and played that game well into my teens and it left a huge footprint on gaming for me, mostly the dungeon networks within the game i spent hours trying to explore.  I saw a few screenshots of "Legend of Grimrock", and that was all i could think of. After playing it, It seems like a complete graphical overhaul of the traditional dungeon crawler mechanics, with more puzzles and exploring to do.The addition of mods (steam workshop) will bring fresh life into this game for a long time. I found the official level (story?) a bit hard to get into. But tried a go at some of the dungeons made by other players and found those more entertaining at the beggining. The engine that powers the game is top class, and somewhat unique. That it's also available on Linux (wooo!) is an added bonus.9/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
27, 2012
												So, you want an old school RPG adventure ? This is it ! Legend Of Grimrock starts you off with 4 prisoners, in a mountain, consisting of 13 levels. These levels are filled with puzzles, evil creatures, traps and more and, obviously, it gets increasingly difficult along the way.However, the difficulty is a bit random at times. Near the end it took me literally minutes to take down one enemy, even though I had some proper spells and weapons. There are moments where you will be overwhelmed by quite a few enemies. Remember to save often, and try not to lose any of your party members before you reached the end of a level. I had to finish a level with just one rogue and it took me 3-4x longer than it should've.The game can be finished in about 10-12 hours (in-game time) but in reality it should take you about twice as long. You will die several times, and some puzzles require thinking, experimenting or just plain luck. But despite the difficulty, I did have a great time with it ![Rating: 82/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 13, 2014
												A modern take on the old-school tile-based dungeon crawler, was something of a surprise hit. Blending a close to perfect mix of horror, suspense, mystery, puzzles, and combat, Legend of Grimrock enticed my inner adventurer. The game itself is quite enjoyable, the grim-dark atmosphere lends itself perfectly to the setting, and the tile-based movement adds an interesting mechanic to it all. The is a game where you will make mistakes, there’s no avoiding that, you will fumble and fall and lose party members and grumble as you backtrack to a crystal. You’ll jump and curse when spiders sneak up on you, groan and rage as traps trigger and surround you with enemies, and kick yourself for not saving more often. You’ll experiment in the skill tree and find out that you’ve invested in something useless, or that you’ve given points wrong, or expended one-use items on the wrong character. Sometimes you’ll wish you’d taken the other loot, or wondered what was in the other locked room, so you’ll reload and find out, then compare before reloading again and deciding. You’ll rage as monsters surround you, you’ll rage as you find a character suddenly out of ammo, mana, poisoned, or just plain dead. You’ll rage as you run from Ogres, you’ll rage as Fire Elementals hit your back-row characters, you’ll rage as you’re confronted with new horrors the dungeon has to offer. But most of all, you will rage at the puzzles.The game does not hold your hand, which is both beautiful and mildly infuriating at times. There’s a lot of trial an error when it comes to solving puzzles, and you will die a lot trying. But that’s what this game is, a lot of trial and error. It can be harsh, but it’s never unfair, so long as you use your brain and save every 5 minutes. The only genuine complaint I have with the game is the inventory/loot system; space was simple to manage so long as you saved your sacks and boxes, but the weight mechanic was a little challenging at times, when I discover that the Kayran Nipple I just looted and put in a character’s inventory has weighed them down and has made the party slow as hell. What really got me was that there was no loot selling or anything like that, things just became obsolete and you had no reason to keep them, other than maybe convenient replacements for rocks.All in all I love this game to death, and had that rare compulsion to play it every second I had free time, though the game is best enjoyed, in my opinion, in longer sessions. That way you remember all the little details you were going over and you don’t miss out on something. That being said, I went over the entire dungeon with a fine-toothed come and still managed to miss some secrets, as the statistics will tell you. Half-way through my first playthrough I realized my lizardman rogue was relatively useless when I could have just gone double fighter mage combo, since I had teched him into ranged and throwing. And that was a mistake. You MUST specialize your character if you want to survive, if you choose to go down swords, you stick with swords, if you want axes, don’t switch out for maces because you found one and it was better, and try to keep to one or two disciplines of magic.For anyone who likes grim-dark fantasy, dungeon crawling, RPG’s, mystery, puzzles, and/or tile-based combat, Legend of Grimrock is definitely a must. Your inner loot-♥♥♥♥♥ will be pleased, your inner puzzler will be perplexed, and your inner adventurer will be grinning all the while. Enter Mount Grimrock, and make your way to the horrors within, best of luck.

content:
2016
												A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through. Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

content:
2016
												Nostalgia FTW.  This will bring back fond memories of the dungeon crawlers of yore.  They even have a mode where there is no automap so you can sharpen your pencils and get out the graph paper (with an achievement for completing the game this way, naturally).   The setup is basic - you create 4 characters, chosing between classes (Fighter, Rogue, Mage) and races (human, minotaur, insectoid, and lizardmen).  You have the basic stats such as strength, dexterity, willpower, and vitality, and are given a pool of points to assign them at the beginning as well as selecting a couple of traits to your character (Athletic, agile, strong mind, etc).  Your initial stats will only be increased by leveling up skills - and they display the complete tree and bonuses earned with each level so you can plan accordingly.  For the base game, there is a good mix of combat and puzzles to solve, though items and maps are static - no random loot here.  However, the game comes with a dungeon editor and there is a healthy selection in the Steam Workshop to give you plenty of replayability.I've beaten the game twice - the second time was a bit of achievement farming as well as trying different character builds.  The sound is adequate - no award winning voicework apart from some grunts, there are just a couple of cutscenes, all of which can be clicked through very quickly, and the bones of the story are pretty bare.  You're all convicts that have been awarded a pardon - which you receive once you are cast into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock.  From there, you are working your way down, following the path of some other criminal who left notes behind that provide a little bit of background, clues to puzzles, and so on. This is NOT turn-based - you click each character's action and wait for the cooldowns to expire before that character can act again. As such, you can maneuver around in combat, dodging, moving out of range, or even circling around behind the enemy for a backstabbing attack (if your rogue has that skill).I recommend the game for fans of the old RPG crawlers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												Ok, I just marathoned through Grimrock 1 and 2 and thought I would conclude that with a concise review.In short : the games are unbelievably good. Admittedly, this was the first time I've ever played a first person dungeon crawler with classic grid-based movement, but there is very little I can actually criticize.The puzzles are extremely well designed. Even though it usually took me few minutes to go from "This ♥♥♥♥ makes no sense at all, what the hell!" to "ohhhh, I get it!", it felt all the more rewarding when I finally managed to solve a particularly difficult puzzle all on my own.The first game manages to create a great gloomy atmosphere, when you delve into pitch black dungeons, devoid of any other human being, and when you can hear the various critters crawl somewhere on the other side of a wall. I would even say, it's not too far off from what a horror game feels like.The successor has a much more open and interconnected world, with differently themed areas, both above and below the surface, similar to how the first Dark Souls approached level design (including the bit where you aimlessly wander around in already cleared areas, looking for the entrance to the next dungeon). It may not be quite as eerie as the first Grimrock game, but the first mimic you encounter in the game will make sure to give you a heart attack regardless.The only thing left to say is : Don't play them on hard mode on your first play through, like I did, or else you're in for a lot of frustration. The games do have a few really cheap moments, the second one even more so than the first one. Because if there's one thing the developers really like, it's trying to make you fall down into a monster infested trap pit, which spells inevitable death. Few things are more infuriating than finding and activating a hidden switch on a wall, only to be mauled by a dozen monsters crawling in from all directions a few seconds later. Now, combine that with an incredibly clunky combat system (Grid-based attacks and movement. In real time. Why...?) which in itself poses enough of a challenge, when enemies can kill your front line in two hits, and you'll find yourself dangerously close to throwing something valuable out of the window. I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one who would have loved to have turn based battles, like in Wizardry 8 for example, in these games.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This is how a dungeon crawler is done. It's really old school with lots of modern elements.So, what's the story? Well, there sort of isn't a story, ok, yes, there is, but it's not so essential to the main plot. The plot is that three people accused of crimes are thrown into a dunegon and must escape. So they must survive while there are monsters everywhere, disgusting food, a strange dream that happens sometimes when you rest, creepy sounds and amazing atmosphere. The graphics add so much to the atmosphere too because they look very amazing and somehow this game runs very well on my terrible PC. I wish more games did that.There are 3 main parts to this game and I will review each aspect one by one:CombatPuzzle SolvingExplorationCombat-The combat in this game is an old school style one, you're party is in 4 people all linked together and you walk on square tiles. You have to gather up weapons from monsters, hidden rooms and exploring the place as so. The magic combat system and the magic system in general is you have to combine a certain combination of runes. You can find these combinations on scrolls which you find and by leveling up the certain types of skills in the game. Speaking of the skills, the skills are pretty much subclasses in classes. The 3 classes in this game are fighter, rouge and mage. (There's a fourth one too but you will have to discover that for yourself) Each class has different abilities, attributes, purposes, uses, etc. There's also traits you can have on each character. There's lots to choose from and some races have their own trait. The 4 races are Human, Minotaur, Lizardman and Insectoid. Each are good for their own class, like how the Lizardman makes a good rogue and how the minotaur makes a good fighter.Puzzle solving-The puzzles in this game are diffucult. I had a LONG time trying to solve them. But after solving all of them, it was all worth it since it was fun and rewarding.Exploration-Without exploration, I don't think this game would've been so great. There are TONS of secrets everywhere. Some are easy to find, some take forever to find. For all those loot lovers out there, you will love this game because of all the loot and what it takes to get it. To go into a little more depth of exploration is the moving system, to turn you can't just turn all the way around, to do that, you would have to turn sideways and look sideways again since you look always in a 90 degree angle.To conclude, I would love to say Legend of Grimrock is a great modern day game and I would recommend it to anyone.

content:
ber 12, 2014
												Giving a simple thumbs-up or thumbs-down to Legend of Grimrock seems to me to miss the point of the game; it was consciously designed for a very specific audience, and your enjoyment will depend upon your belonging to said audience. I'd describe Grimrock as a puzzle game with an RPG overlay. You're dumped on top of a mountain and have to fight and puzzle your way through a series of dungeon levels in order to get to the exit at the bottom. There's an opening graphic about being condemned to the maze and offered a slim chance at survival as punishment for unspecified crimes, like eating puppies or promoting Justin Bieber's music or somesuch. Unimportant; it's a reason for your four-person party to wind up stuck in a dungeon. Players of the Recent Might and Magic X: Legacy will find it has less involved, less tactically sophisticated combat but much tougher puzzles (it pains me to admit that I got stumped fairly early on); you look for a hidden switch that opens a door somewhere on the other end of the level that leads to a dead end with another switch disguised as a torch sconce that when pulled opens the gate you saw three turns back which leads to a scrap of paper with a password on it for that magical barrier you couldn't get past before...I've given Legend of Grimrock a thumbs-up because it seems to do what it set out to do: it provides a series of tougher and tougher dungeon puzzles for the player to obsess over, with some simple combat to leaven it. The game's a bit like extra-dark chocolate in that respect: people who already find it to their taste will love it, while people who don't will find it has a bitter, gritty flavour that sort of reminds them of something they like.

content:
1, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock is one of a very small litter of games that attempts to create a classic dungeon crawler similar to those of the old days such as Dungeon Master and succeeds in not only emulating that style, but updating it enough to make it a refreshing experience for modern gamers, as well as a familiar one.A feature I found to be charming (as well as terrifying) was the option to play the game on a Classic difficulty that forces you to draw your own maps out on grid paper, much like old pen-and-paper tabletop games. I myself haven't been brave enough to give this playthrough a try yet, but I still find it to be a wonderful option for true gluttons of punishment.As deeply rewarding as it is challenging, with lots of replay value, and great Steam Workshop options to keep the game new for even the most frequent players, LoG is a for sure winner. I'll be eagerly awaiting the release of the second game, ready to brave the dangers between the dungeon walls once more.

												$15 or less gets you a remarkably well-designed retro-style dungeon crawler, complete with a four player party (of Humans, Minotaurs, Lizardmen and Insectoids), a wide range of devious traps and puzzles (which you really don't see in RPGs anymore), and some very challenging fights.It has all of the features of a classic first-person RPG - tile-based movement, dying of starvation, reading bits of the story off scrolls, and the like - mixed with the accessibility and graphics of a modern, big-ish budget RPG...so it's both nostaglic and a refreshing change of pace for the genre? Eh, I'm crapping on, just buy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 13, 2013
												Not since Portal have I played a puzzle game that made me feel both stupid and empowered when I figured out the answer was right in front of my face. Legend of Grimrock combines an old-school dungeon crawler mixed with puzzles and RPG elements.  Synopsis: You control a group of 4 prisoners trying to escape Grimrock by solving puzzles and fighting monsters. Puzzles can be as simple as a hidden button on a wall or as complex that things may take time and patience to solve. Gameplay: The best way I can describe this game is if you mixed D&D and Myst, with tons of aggravation. The Legend of Grimrock isn’t as one dimensional as the art style and movement may lead you to believe. Many of the puzzles will leave you scratching your head and swearing there isn’t a solution. The other aspect of the game which I believe could use some work is the battle system. As intricate as the puzzles can be, the system to fight monsters throughout gets repetitive and leaves a lot to be desired. It’s a mix between real time and turn based, with a focus on the formation of your team. If your characters use all short range abilities, you have to swap one of the two, for the one you want to attack. Many monsters can be defeated without much strategy and sometimes become a hindrance to trying to solve a puzzle. There are four classes you can choose from as you customize your perfect party, but very little direction or tutorial on how to use each class. I found myself having to look up a guide on how to use a mage to even understand what magic could be used. I have logged thirty-eight hours on this title (some of it was afk during a multiplayer game), but at less than $5, 20 hours of engrossing gameplay and a strong community following, this game is more than worth it.Positive: +Challenging puzzles are intricate enough to make you feel clever+Game can be saved at any point.+Large community following where content can be downloaded.Negative-Battle system can get repetitive.-Not all classes are created equal. Art Style/Graphics:  Think old school, first person, dungeon crawler. This game is a great blend of classic nostalgia with a jolt of current 3d graphics. Much of the game in spent in the darkness with two to three walls around you, but this doesn’t mean the creators were lazy. Attention is paid to simple cracks in the wall, to how the light bounces off each wall. To speak more about the lighting; this plays a huge role on the tone of the gameplay. The torches on the walls (or the ones you drop on the ground) limit vision to what can be around the next turn, which makes you feel like you are actually there.Positive:+Lighting is engaging.+Can be played on lower-end computers.+Can be played in Windowed ModeNegative:-Characters and enemies could be upgraded.Soundtrack/Sound effects: This was one of the biggest negatives to the game for me. For the 20 hours I played, much of the time was spent trying to solve puzzles. To solve puzzles you have to explore the dungeon, often falling to lower parts. Hearing my characters yell as they were falling, over and over, got very annoying. This is only increased by the often reused sounds of the characters attacking and grunting in every fight they encounter. On a positive note, the minor sounds of metal doors closing, walls moving, or crackling of the fire, add a realistic aspect and can be heard in surround sound.Positive:+Simple sounds of environment Negative:-Repetitive Cost: I personally bought this game in a Humble Bundle (only paying $5), but that being said, I would wait for this game to go on sale. $14 (full price) is a bit too much for the amount of gameplay in the standalone. At 75% off ($3.75) a case can be made. This does not include the amount of community related additions on the workshop; which is extensivePositive:+HUGE community created contentNegative:-Full price not worth standalone

content:
1, 2013
												For years I've been wanting to play a modernized old school first person dungeon crawl/RPGs. I tried going back and playing older ones like might and magic games but they just don't cut it over time. All I can say is Legend of Grimrock is EXACTLY what I've been waiting for. It takes all the fun, excitement, and strategy out of those old games and brings it to the current level of gameplay. It removes all the buggyness of older games, it replaces the confusingly blurred graphics where it's easy to miss an important item with beautiful design, poor puzzles with strategic challenges, choppy fighting with challenging battles, etc. I LOVED this game, I had so much fun playing it, and with the added function of a popular mod community and a dungeon editor it is really a top tier experience. If you like RPGs, or dungeon crawls, or have been craving what I have then look no further: this game is TONS of fun.

content:
15, 2012
												Grimrock... I have never had a game ever before take me back so very far into my gaming past. Way back, there was a game called Dungeon Master. It was the first adventure game I played, and this game replicates it perfectly in terms of gameplay. The game engine, the puzzles, everything about it just screams that this is one game that will take up a lot of your time.The gameplay itself is solid. You move on a grid, everything happens in real time, you have to eat, you sleep to regain health and mana, your torches burn out. So much management that most modern adventure games seem to miss, that add to the experience. The puzzles are well thought out, take effort to solve and are satisfying to get past. Combat is fast paced, requiring thought as well as a fast clicking finger.This is one game that remains true to the classic, old adventure games of gaming yore. Whether you remember that time or not, this is one experience not to be missed.

content:
2016
												A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through. Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

content:
2016
												Nostalgia FTW.  This will bring back fond memories of the dungeon crawlers of yore.  They even have a mode where there is no automap so you can sharpen your pencils and get out the graph paper (with an achievement for completing the game this way, naturally).   The setup is basic - you create 4 characters, chosing between classes (Fighter, Rogue, Mage) and races (human, minotaur, insectoid, and lizardmen).  You have the basic stats such as strength, dexterity, willpower, and vitality, and are given a pool of points to assign them at the beginning as well as selecting a couple of traits to your character (Athletic, agile, strong mind, etc).  Your initial stats will only be increased by leveling up skills - and they display the complete tree and bonuses earned with each level so you can plan accordingly.  For the base game, there is a good mix of combat and puzzles to solve, though items and maps are static - no random loot here.  However, the game comes with a dungeon editor and there is a healthy selection in the Steam Workshop to give you plenty of replayability.I've beaten the game twice - the second time was a bit of achievement farming as well as trying different character builds.  The sound is adequate - no award winning voicework apart from some grunts, there are just a couple of cutscenes, all of which can be clicked through very quickly, and the bones of the story are pretty bare.  You're all convicts that have been awarded a pardon - which you receive once you are cast into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock.  From there, you are working your way down, following the path of some other criminal who left notes behind that provide a little bit of background, clues to puzzles, and so on. This is NOT turn-based - you click each character's action and wait for the cooldowns to expire before that character can act again. As such, you can maneuver around in combat, dodging, moving out of range, or even circling around behind the enemy for a backstabbing attack (if your rogue has that skill).I recommend the game for fans of the old RPG crawlers.

content:
, 2014
												LEGEND OF GRIMROCK is so perfect in its execution of old school retro hack and slash its supernatural. The balance of puzzle difficulty and battling enemies is as perfect as humanly possible. Dungeons are buetifully designed in their retro design ala DUNGEON MASTER. Lighting and shadows give an eerie haunting ambience as they flicker about walls and cast their forms on stone floors. Some times shadows are moving about violently due to some ghastly horror standing in front of a light source about to pounce on my party of four dungeon prisoners trying to survive to earn their freedom. Monster design and animations are amazing and terrifying. Its like actually being in the world of DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS with familiar classics from the table top games gracing ones eye with their artistic beauty. Running into new enemies is a major adrenaline rush bringing back memories of playing EYE OF THE BEHOLDER etc where part of the reward of continuing was seeing the great looking monsters. Combat is a strategic joy as giant bats lunge and fly at my party repeatedly as we try to time our acttacks for best effect and hopefully a critical or two. Animations really add to the immersion making one get lost in the excitement of the moment. Alot of times i'll find myself having to acttack from long range or retreat lest my entire party is slaughtered with no one left alive to bring them to huge blue crystals which can bring your fellow adventurers back from the dead. Sound effects are subtle and all consuming adding to the realism of the experiance with plenty of retro inducing emotional thrills. Its nice for a change to actually hear my characters give a blood curdling scream as they die compared to other rpgs where they hardly give out a whimper. So far the only music i have heard is the intro theme which is fabulous alive with old school adventure as if from a 1980s Conan movie or b-movie. While traveling in dungeons of Grimrock my ears are sweetly embraced by spooky ambient sound effects. Character creation and developement is handled very well with a comfortable amount of detail to make each adventurer in ones party feel unique. You can add points to strength, dexterity etc and also put points into certain character based skills only available to certain types of characters. So certain skills will only be available to a particular class such as a rogue and others to a mage etc. If you loved old school hardcore rpgs back in the day such as Dungeon Master and Black Crypt you owe it to your happiness to get LEGEND OF GRIMROCK. There really isnt any excuse. Just pick up a STEAM card at your local game shop such as GAMESTOP or BEST BUY add some money and go buy the game online without worrying about the hassle of credit cards etc. LEGEND OF GRIMROCK. Truly it is legend.

y 8, 2013
												A much longer game than expected.  Somehow I assumed it would be shorter since it has downloadable levels through Steamworks.I enjoyed playing it since it is a throw back to the original days of PC gaming and RPG's.  Took me about 17 hours to complete with breaks/getting lost.  I tried not to use any walkthroughs but I had to at the last area only to go... duh....The combat is slow pace to start but by floor 8 out of 13, you need to start being fast and moving around monsters or you'll die.  You can create your own team/race/class set up with four chars and create your own playstyle.  I had two tanks (sword/mace) and two mages (fire/earth).The downside is I started to get bored around floor 9, but decided to rush to the end and beat it.  Luckily floors 11-13 are somewhat qucik.  Cool if you dig old PC gamestyle, but most will likely be turned off by a game like this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
22, 2014
												I used to have a board game called Hero Quest when I was a kid.  I loved it!  It was a gateway game to harder dru...erm, games like D&D, Vampire, and other table top games and eventually back to board games (I'm a proud board game geek).  Coincidentally, I also began to take a second look at dungeon crawlers.  Before this time, my largest exposure to first person RPGs of the like was Bard's Tale and I hated that game.  I bought "Eye of the Beholder" and "Shining in the Darkness" back then.  I dabbled with them, but quickly moved onto other RPGs.  Fast forward twelve years later and I picked up and finally beat Shining, giving it more respect and reigniting an appreciation for that style of RPG.  Two years after Shining, I beat Phantasy Star.  Two years after Phantasy Star, I beat Shadowgate and now Legend of Grimrock.I love top ten lists, cause I'm a sucker for order. Given the four dungeon crawls I beat, Grimrock would rank second after Shining.  The game is great, but I'm not sure it was enough to pull me back for more.  I enjoyed the opening music and the sound effects were atmospheric.  Graphics are decent and are done well for being programmed in Lua, but the effects do make certain reflective surfaces appear artificially shiny.  Gameplay is pretty straightforward.  Find better gear and attack bad guys.  The battle system is very simplistic as it really just comes down to right clicking.  The joy in combat actually comes from side stepping and dodging enemies to smack them.  It really is pleasing to be able to pull this off flawlessly after some practice. If done correctly, you can go floors before even getting hit. I played on Hard and Old School mode and it hurt me emotionally. I ended up getting lost several times, despite best efforts at maps and some enemies made me swear bad things against their offspring. The story is nearly nonexistent, but tidbits of flavor in the form of Toorum's notes and the ever detached presence pushing you forward is enough as the story takes back seat to the puzzles on each floor.  "You're dumped into a dungeon, find your way out," is what is it comes down to.  The final boss was unexpected until you got down to the 12th floor and the battle wasn't overly difficult, but was a tad too long as I would dish out a few hits, drop down to the lower floor, heal, save, repeat.   The artwork for the ending is well done and I was surprised that a game this well made was done by four people.  It's worth a play if you're into this type of thing.

content:
, 2014
												LEGEND OF GRIMROCK is so perfect in its execution of old school retro hack and slash its supernatural. The balance of puzzle difficulty and battling enemies is as perfect as humanly possible. Dungeons are buetifully designed in their retro design ala DUNGEON MASTER. Lighting and shadows give an eerie haunting ambience as they flicker about walls and cast their forms on stone floors. Some times shadows are moving about violently due to some ghastly horror standing in front of a light source about to pounce on my party of four dungeon prisoners trying to survive to earn their freedom. Monster design and animations are amazing and terrifying. Its like actually being in the world of DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS with familiar classics from the table top games gracing ones eye with their artistic beauty. Running into new enemies is a major adrenaline rush bringing back memories of playing EYE OF THE BEHOLDER etc where part of the reward of continuing was seeing the great looking monsters. Combat is a strategic joy as giant bats lunge and fly at my party repeatedly as we try to time our acttacks for best effect and hopefully a critical or two. Animations really add to the immersion making one get lost in the excitement of the moment. Alot of times i'll find myself having to acttack from long range or retreat lest my entire party is slaughtered with no one left alive to bring them to huge blue crystals which can bring your fellow adventurers back from the dead. Sound effects are subtle and all consuming adding to the realism of the experiance with plenty of retro inducing emotional thrills. Its nice for a change to actually hear my characters give a blood curdling scream as they die compared to other rpgs where they hardly give out a whimper. So far the only music i have heard is the intro theme which is fabulous alive with old school adventure as if from a 1980s Conan movie or b-movie. While traveling in dungeons of Grimrock my ears are sweetly embraced by spooky ambient sound effects. Character creation and developement is handled very well with a comfortable amount of detail to make each adventurer in ones party feel unique. You can add points to strength, dexterity etc and also put points into certain character based skills only available to certain types of characters. So certain skills will only be available to a particular class such as a rogue and others to a mage etc. If you loved old school hardcore rpgs back in the day such as Dungeon Master and Black Crypt you owe it to your happiness to get LEGEND OF GRIMROCK. There really isnt any excuse. Just pick up a STEAM card at your local game shop such as GAMESTOP or BEST BUY add some money and go buy the game online without worrying about the hassle of credit cards etc. LEGEND OF GRIMROCK. Truly it is legend.

												9/10 So i bought this game a while ago, but didn't really start logging many hours into it until recently. This game is great--if you're a fan of oldschool dungeon crawler games, I highly suggest you look into the Legend of Grimrock series. A few notes:-This game is fairly easy to add content to, such as extra player portraits-Does not lag, seems to run pretty well on most machines-You can choose to fill in the map as you go, classic style-Doesn't have turn based gameplay, but rather each character has a cooldown on their weapons-Spell system is intrigueing and somewhat reminiscent of magicka-Straightforward gameplay-Challenging without being unnecessarily difficult-Graphics are okay, not top of the class but still decentIf you like puzzles or dungeon crawlers, you'll like this game. Try it.

content:
2016
												Nostalgia FTW.  This will bring back fond memories of the dungeon crawlers of yore.  They even have a mode where there is no automap so you can sharpen your pencils and get out the graph paper (with an achievement for completing the game this way, naturally).   The setup is basic - you create 4 characters, chosing between classes (Fighter, Rogue, Mage) and races (human, minotaur, insectoid, and lizardmen).  You have the basic stats such as strength, dexterity, willpower, and vitality, and are given a pool of points to assign them at the beginning as well as selecting a couple of traits to your character (Athletic, agile, strong mind, etc).  Your initial stats will only be increased by leveling up skills - and they display the complete tree and bonuses earned with each level so you can plan accordingly.  For the base game, there is a good mix of combat and puzzles to solve, though items and maps are static - no random loot here.  However, the game comes with a dungeon editor and there is a healthy selection in the Steam Workshop to give you plenty of replayability.I've beaten the game twice - the second time was a bit of achievement farming as well as trying different character builds.  The sound is adequate - no award winning voicework apart from some grunts, there are just a couple of cutscenes, all of which can be clicked through very quickly, and the bones of the story are pretty bare.  You're all convicts that have been awarded a pardon - which you receive once you are cast into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock.  From there, you are working your way down, following the path of some other criminal who left notes behind that provide a little bit of background, clues to puzzles, and so on. This is NOT turn-based - you click each character's action and wait for the cooldowns to expire before that character can act again. As such, you can maneuver around in combat, dodging, moving out of range, or even circling around behind the enemy for a backstabbing attack (if your rogue has that skill).I recommend the game for fans of the old RPG crawlers.

content:
2016
												A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through. Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

You actually feel like you're trapped inside the dungeon; you actually feel scared when you know there's a stronger enemy ahead, instead of simply being more careful; you actually feel that if you take damage you're screwed, unlike some games *ahem* CoD *ahem*. Honestly, the only not so great thing that I can think about this game is that *sometimes* you move 2 squares instead of 1 because you tapped w twice by accident, which may cause you to fall into a pit. If you like RPGs, dungeon crawlers OR puzzle games, GET THIS. It's worth every cent and every minute you spend on it.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This is how a dungeon crawler is done. It's really old school with lots of modern elements.So, what's the story? Well, there sort of isn't a story, ok, yes, there is, but it's not so essential to the main plot. The plot is that three people accused of crimes are thrown into a dunegon and must escape. So they must survive while there are monsters everywhere, disgusting food, a strange dream that happens sometimes when you rest, creepy sounds and amazing atmosphere. The graphics add so much to the atmosphere too because they look very amazing and somehow this game runs very well on my terrible PC. I wish more games did that.There are 3 main parts to this game and I will review each aspect one by one:CombatPuzzle SolvingExplorationCombat-The combat in this game is an old school style one, you're party is in 4 people all linked together and you walk on square tiles. You have to gather up weapons from monsters, hidden rooms and exploring the place as so. The magic combat system and the magic system in general is you have to combine a certain combination of runes. You can find these combinations on scrolls which you find and by leveling up the certain types of skills in the game. Speaking of the skills, the skills are pretty much subclasses in classes. The 3 classes in this game are fighter, rouge and mage. (There's a fourth one too but you will have to discover that for yourself) Each class has different abilities, attributes, purposes, uses, etc. There's also traits you can have on each character. There's lots to choose from and some races have their own trait. The 4 races are Human, Minotaur, Lizardman and Insectoid. Each are good for their own class, like how the Lizardman makes a good rogue and how the minotaur makes a good fighter.Puzzle solving-The puzzles in this game are diffucult. I had a LONG time trying to solve them. But after solving all of them, it was all worth it since it was fun and rewarding.Exploration-Without exploration, I don't think this game would've been so great. There are TONS of secrets everywhere. Some are easy to find, some take forever to find. For all those loot lovers out there, you will love this game because of all the loot and what it takes to get it. To go into a little more depth of exploration is the moving system, to turn you can't just turn all the way around, to do that, you would have to turn sideways and look sideways again since you look always in a 90 degree angle.To conclude, I would love to say Legend of Grimrock is a great modern day game and I would recommend it to anyone.

content:
2016
												Nostalgia FTW.  This will bring back fond memories of the dungeon crawlers of yore.  They even have a mode where there is no automap so you can sharpen your pencils and get out the graph paper (with an achievement for completing the game this way, naturally).   The setup is basic - you create 4 characters, chosing between classes (Fighter, Rogue, Mage) and races (human, minotaur, insectoid, and lizardmen).  You have the basic stats such as strength, dexterity, willpower, and vitality, and are given a pool of points to assign them at the beginning as well as selecting a couple of traits to your character (Athletic, agile, strong mind, etc).  Your initial stats will only be increased by leveling up skills - and they display the complete tree and bonuses earned with each level so you can plan accordingly.  For the base game, there is a good mix of combat and puzzles to solve, though items and maps are static - no random loot here.  However, the game comes with a dungeon editor and there is a healthy selection in the Steam Workshop to give you plenty of replayability.I've beaten the game twice - the second time was a bit of achievement farming as well as trying different character builds.  The sound is adequate - no award winning voicework apart from some grunts, there are just a couple of cutscenes, all of which can be clicked through very quickly, and the bones of the story are pretty bare.  You're all convicts that have been awarded a pardon - which you receive once you are cast into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock.  From there, you are working your way down, following the path of some other criminal who left notes behind that provide a little bit of background, clues to puzzles, and so on. This is NOT turn-based - you click each character's action and wait for the cooldowns to expire before that character can act again. As such, you can maneuver around in combat, dodging, moving out of range, or even circling around behind the enemy for a backstabbing attack (if your rogue has that skill).I recommend the game for fans of the old RPG crawlers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
												A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through. Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

content:
12, 2012
												Summary:Grimrock is a first person (first party in this case) dungeon crawl.  If you've ever heard/played a game called Stonekeep (late 1990s), you'll enjoy this game too.  Well designed, immersive, and an absolutely beautiful sound track.  Some skill is required to be a magic caster / use magic in your party, but if you get good at it, you really feel you've earned the title "mage."Overall Score:  Worth Getting (Niche game)  -- ( 79/100)Gameplay:  (56/60 points)Mechanics (35/35 points) – rules/physics/noticeable glitchesI have never encountered any bugs while playing Grimrock.  The rules of the world fit very well with the challenges you face and you never feel like the game is cheating.Controls (8/10 points) – ease of operation / button dynamicsControls are very basic, left, right, back, forward, casting is difficult, but in a good way where you feel really good when you successfully cast a spell.  My only beef with the controls was inventory managment.  Trying to maintain 4 peoples inventory was very cumbersome at times.Difficulty ( 5/5 points) – how hard is it to progress & does this difficulty work for or against the playerThe game trains you as you go.  The first few levels are about learning how things work.  It's a good build up and by later in the game, it's about exploration, adapting and facing challenges that force you to use everything you've learned up to that point.Immersion ( 4/5 points) –  very subjective:  Being drawn into the gameThe environments are realistic enough and the sounds and music will make you forget about everything around you.  The desire to save as often as possible and searching for secrets areas and having to look up a few solutions was the only thing that broke immersion for me.Fun ( 3/5 points)– very subjective: other enjoyment factorsVERY fun, but not so fun that I actually finished the game.  It was still excellent though, I've gotten further into this game than most.Content:  (20/35 points)Story (13/15 points) – Does it exist, coherent, presentation of, and does it enhance game play?The opening was excellent, there's little scraps of papers and books that tell you more of the story thorugh the ponderings of a former "inmate."  Also every level of the game tells a different story and as you move further in, the very walls and status hint at darker things that have gone into the formation of Grimrock.  I can't say that the story is deep, but it is enjoyable. Characters (5/10 points) – Interesting, well developed, work with gameplay and storyThe characters are fairly standard fare for your Dungeons and Dragons -esque setting, but the manual had some great backstory on each.  It doesn't play into the game, but was good flavor text.“S.S.D.D.” value (2/10 points) – abilities, roles, tools, NPCs, and general world setting uniquenessVery typical for a dungeon crawl. Gamer Parent Factors:  (3/5 GOLDEN points)- (WIN) Ability to save / pause and come back later to pick it up right away again- (WIN) Ability to progress during short gameplay sessions (30 mins – 1.5 hours)- (WIN) Replay value and game length not related to required repetitive grinding to increase stats-  (NO)  Ability to play game with spouse or offspring-  (NO)  Availability on multiple platformsGamerDad Game Reviews -- Purpose and CriteriaThe purpose of GamerDad Game reviews is to evaluate ‘aged’ games that have been on the market long enough to experience a substantial price drop from their original industry standard price. Reviewing games towards the end of their life cycle will offer an updated consumer valuation of the game based on if known issues have been fixed since release, value of optional DLC (Downloadable Content made available after initial game release) to gameplay, and if the entertainment return on investment is worth the new price point.

content:
14, 2012
												Lengends of Grimrock, what the hell is that?  My first thought as I clicked on the link.  To my utter surprise this appeared to be a leap back in time to the wonderful dungeon exploration days of Dungeon Master & Eye of the Beholder.  Not only have they captured the soul from the Dungeon crawler era, they've improved upon it.  For the uneducated amongst you, Dungeon Master let you create a party of 4 and turn by turn you'd explore a dungeon mapping as you went, solving riddles and nasty puzzles whilst fighting creatures way too powerful for your team.  LoG has this option but wisely have included automapping (on squared maps for authenticity) with ability to write notes.  Graphics and sound are atmospheric with level design that not only tips the hat to the former greats in the genre but pushes it beyond.  I'm 5 levels in and hooked.  Each room you get to has hidden dangers and rewards to find.  The turn based mechanics have been sped up.  If you don't move the enemy will keep going.
